number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												One of the best Paradox creations of all time. While for experienced in RTS games players it is noob-friendly, it can be actually quite confusing and complicated for new comers to understand the concept and purpose of all the factors included. As the name of the game says, it's mainly concentrated in Europe as the timeline in the game goes from the years 1444-1821. The game adapts many features and it's very comfortable for the user to actually control everything, the simulation of economy, war and diplomacy is really well done and there are many unique features and events that could help you even more. While there is a tutorial, for the new-comers it won't be the best of help. The game is purely built on historical map (almost entirely correct) and after you pick a date and begin with a country, you can change the concept of history entirely. Although mentioned that the war mechanics were good, they aren't exactly ideal. or sometimes realistic. There aren't any really factors that influence the combat other than the terrain, manpower and.. some rolling dice. You can accept it as a kind of a chance game or even gambling. The diplomacy branch is good on the other side. There are special points - Administrative, Military and Diplomatic points and each of them have their sole purpose. I won't go exactly in detail about them, but there are special 'people' - Diplomats, Merchants, Missionaries and so on. This is the mechanic I really like, as it's a defining point of the game and it can perform many actions. Another factor is the monarch (or the ruler), and he's a pretty valuable in the game too. There are many skipped parts but this is the main look of the game and its welcoming to the people.TL;DR: Like Strategy? Like History? This is the game for you. Give it a go!9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
 Europa Universalis IV The Sequel to the critcally acclaimed Europa Universalis III did not disappoint.  With a variety of a new features mounted on a brand new Clausewitz 2.0 engine the game is much more smoother and less clunkier in most aspects, having streamlined alot of the chores into a simple click of a button. Detaching for a siege,Patrolling,rebel supression etc is just a click of a button away as compared to EU3 where you had to manually detach men for a siege for example.As the name might suggest,the scale is colossal spanning 7 conintents and 5 oceans (barring Antartica) the world is your playground. There is no clearly defined objective or motive , it is all up to you ,the player. Playing as England you can try to beat france in the hundred years war and rewrite history. If your a fan of the Romans, you can try to restore the roman empire. Take the balkans back from the ottomans and push them out of asia minor,maybe expand into western europe and reconquer the city of Rome. You can even explore a randomized new world with the Conquest of Paradise Expansion. The possibilities are endless.However,as with any games,there are definitely bugs and flaws. The Protectecrate System as of now is essentially useless,they do not fight in battles and only give you trade power. Your Protectecrates system to benefit more off you than you do off them. Colonial Nations are abit buggy as well,other colonial nations can declalre war on your colonial nation without even calling you to arms, so if for example a 20 province colony of portugal declares war on a 5 province colony of yours,you can not do anything except watch them eat your colony up unless miracously they win that war.There are still many more bugs which i have not pointed out. but you get the ideaThat being said though Europa Universalis 4 is still definitely worth getting , it's replayability value is practically endless and if you have Crusader Kings 2 and the CK2 to EUIV converter , you can start a game in CK2 and Continue all the way to the end of EU4 and maybe even Victoria If there is a converter.9/10 Rating

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												It's alright, maybe worth an hour or two.In all seriousness a really good grand strategy game that is popularly known as the map making simulator, and for good reason.  In this game you paint out your own history in an ever so detailed fasion.  Either creating a grand colonial empire, be a war mongering country, or a simple trade company.  Sure, it may be a little intimidating to get into the game at first, but if you have a friend or watch some videos on it, you should be fine.  I would give the game a 9/10, good content, but there are some small bugs here and there and the dlc is kind of expensive.  You can share dlc with people though in multiplayer if they host it.Cheers :)EDIT: Would still recommend the game but the more I play the it, the more bs i see in the AI and how Paradox is pretty lazy in properly handling them.  AI get more ally slots, more general slots, no attrition for units, no fort maintenance on borders, lower agressive expansion, less base unrest.... you get the idea.  The thing is you can still beat them, I was able to form Italy and dismantle the HRE with a Poland, austria, massive bohemia, lithuania pu group stacked against me that was allied to russia and the ottomans.  So ey, sometimes it comes down to luck.RE EDIT: My notes above are tad bit salty but yes their AI is still fairly trash.  I would now say to buy the game when it's on sale only and I recommend to buy some dlc with the purchase since the base is completely different from a game with dlc.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												I don't play strategic games often, because I cannot find something that gives me a true experience. That happened until i found Europa Universalis. This game gives you the power to do anything. Colonize with Japan and beat Portugal, France and Spain in the colonization race, be the ottomans and conquer Europe. Start a nation in Africa and dominate the world. The possibilities are infinite, and you can experience different endings in multiple playthroughs with the same nation. The learning curve is quick. At the beginning, you can find the game hard, but as time goes by, and after a couple of hours of playing it, you will have no difficulty on playing it. Besides, you have a lot of answered questions in the internet, you just need to google it if you can't find the solution for your problem. Also, the graphics are astonishing, and I really enjoy the multiple maps (diplomatic maps, religion maps, culture maps, etc etc) full of colours, it is really catchy. Even if this is not enough for you, the game presents you with brilliant soundtracks, giving you the feeling that you're really living the experience.I would totally recommend this to any strategic players, it's hard to not love this game. 9/10

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												OK, serious review time.After nearly 900 hours of playing this game, I believe it's appropriate for me to leave an actual, serious review. So this game takes place from 1444 to 1821, so the Renaissance to post Napoleonic Wars, which is a big span of history. You play as a nation trying to find your place in the sun, aspriring to empire-dom and to position you and your nation in the annals of history. You could play as the historical big boys like Castile, Portugal, France, Russia, the Ottomans, etc.Or you could start small. And dream big.This is where the game truly shines. Building yourself up, conquering everyone and everything around you. Sending your people across the seas to build a new home. Constructing the finest army and navy the world has ever seen. Amass a trade empire, steal wealth from your rivals or cleaverly place your merchants in prime cities and ports. Develop your provinces to squeeze as much money, resources and manpower as possible. Build buildings to assist you on your quest to glory, like barracks to improve manpower, marketplaces to squeeze trade out of important provinces or build temples to tax your people more efficiently. Choose idea groups that boost the stats of your nation, like Religious for converting heathen and heretic alike, Quality for easy and quick wars and so on. So what are you waiting for? Pick up a copy and play this beautiful game of grand strategy and conquest. See you at 1000 hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												EUIV is a very well designed game, but the entry cost is a bit high. The tutoral isn't as helpful or as in-depth as it needed to be to serve as a strong introduction to the game; it also was apparently unupdated for patches and DLC/Expansions. After the initial time investment (I spent around 8 hours actually learning how to do various things in the game) and a trip to the wiki (eu4wiki), the massive depth of the game really shines through. The randomness of the game allows for a massive amount of replayability, which combines well with the sheer size of the game to create an experience that can last for hundreds, if not thousands, of hours. There are a few nitpicks, especially when the game refuses to say why something can't be done. There are certain moments when very unrealistic things can really break the immersion and tone of the game which is both a flaw and a testament to how well the rest of the game handles realism.While this certainly isn't something that everyone would like, and there is a good deal of time and effort input required to glean any experience from the game, the reward is an immensely deep and lengthy, yet enjoyable experience.EDIT: A note on the DLC policy of the game: The game is constantly being updated (both with improvements and some poorly thought-out mechanics) and DLC is intended to fund this. The different DLC have very different value-to-cost ratios (Art of War-good, Mare Nostrum-bad), so it's definitely better to buy the DLC on sales, since the total overall cost is a bit absurd. Some of the changes that come with the free patches can be quite divisive, and the reviews for the accompanying DLC often reflect this. The patches also have pretty bad Quality Assurance and often times bugs can remain for months after being added and reported.

												Has a tough learning curve that takes time to overcome. I would recommend watching a 'Let's Play' series to get an idea of how the game works. Jumping in blind can be intimidating and frustrating, so just spend a little time getting a basic idea of what's in store. Stick with it and you will be rewarded with one of the greatest grand strategy games released.Absolutely would recommend this game to anyone who loves strategy. Very few games can offer unique playthroughs with this level of planning and strategy involved. If you play the length of the game, it really has a great sense of growth, development, and progress as you take on challenged and achieve goals. 150+ hrs into this game and I still find new ways to improve from my last playthrough. Only BAD thing is some of the expansions are, essentially, required to play the "full game" at this point. Fortunately, they are priced fairly and after a few games you'll want them anyways. :)10/10

												Europa Universalis IV is one of the most interesting, time-consuming and genre-defining "grand strategy" games ever made.You can control any country in the world (Native American tribes, Mongol Hordes, the pope, Holy Roman Empire) in the Age of Discovery (1444-1805). Every nation, howsoever small, has the chance to become a superpower in colonizing, rading, land war or naval warfare.This game is hard to learn, but if you watch some tutorials, play for yourself, watch some more tutorials and play some more, you acquire the required knowledge to have a lot of fun.Paradox Development Studio is also known for improving their games by adding more stuff (free patches and major game changing DLCs) to the game, even years after the releases.It's definitely worth buying for the full price, if you have enough time to spend.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												Absolutely brilliant grand strategy from Paradox as always. Interesting mechanics, a huge array of choices as who to play, great fun even if you're playing as some minor Asian nation and a brilliant modding community and randomness to each game that provides unlimited replayability. If you want a grand strategy that provides challenge, immersion and depth then this is the game for you.It's not without it's faults, namely it's worryingly large number of bugs, but Paradox is constantly patching and updating the game on an almot monthly basis fixing most as the pop up. Multiplayer can be a bit funny, but I've had great fun playing it online with a few friends, conquering entire continents between us. Furthermore, many nations provide a very interesting situation where you must tread carefully and take risks to advance, which is something I feel lacking in many strategy games. I often find many games lackjing any real sense of risk, more often a simple pattern holding true to each game. EU4 overcomes this rather well. Nations like Najd, Songhai or any of the Infian nations provide great interesting events and challenges, with even more round the corner when the Europeans turn up at your door!Overall I'd rate this an 8/10. I've personally never encountered a single bug, but I'm aware other in the community have to great extent and so it would be foolish to pretend they don't exist. Certainly this game is playable and most of all, fun. If you enjoy any paradox game, you'll enjoy this.

												Europa Universalis is a masterpiece for grand strategy gamers, its complex but everything works fine and is logical. Its always great to play this game: wars, diplomacy, economy, rebels and the colonies. I'm still in my first Playthrough, but I can tell, it's a very well performed mix of all Strategy games we'd had so far (even though it can't compair with the dynasty-system of Crusader Kings 2, BUT only in that part like everything else is better). content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Europa Universalis IV is a very simple game, in theory. You control a nation, from 1444 to 1821, and lead it to world dominaton or commercial dominance or whatever else you want to do, using your military and diplomats to get what you want.In practice, it is incredibly complicated. Every country not controlled by a human is being run by the AI, even if you can't see them. Every other country will react to changes in the political climate as they happen, generally resulting in very unexpected endings. Each country will have its own opinion of yours, influenced by things like who your enemies are, how much land you took in recent wars, what religion your country practices, and even whether or not they just want you dead to begin with.There are a variety of ways to make other countries see more highly of you, just as there are ways to make them want you dead even more than they already did. You can annex smaller neighbors that think highly of you, or you can go to war and dominate your neighbors instead. Each country has a goal, and these goals will change dramatically over the 380 years you have to act. Each country has its own bonuses; the Merchant Republics of Venice and Novgorod are in a great position to amass large quantities of wealth, if they survive. The giants of Muscovy and Austria can easily dominate anyone who tries to oppose them.The question is, what is it you want to do? The Byzantines, driven to near destruction by the Ottomans, can still be led to the restoration of the Roman Empire by anyone willing to lead them there. The Swedes, in the Kalmar Union under Denmark and sure to be annexed, can remove the Danes from their throne and become a colonial empire under the right leadership. There are, without exaggeration, an infinite number of possible directions you can take this game. The El Dorado expansion pack and its custom nation designer only reinforces this; build a Muslim republic in Lithuanian land, conquer Russia with it, and then become an Islamic Russia. Set up a Jewish empire in Ireland and conquer England. Whatever. Go do it.Now, I assume, you're thinking "Ok, that's all good, but how well is it executed?" Flawlessly. The incredibly complex diplomacy system gives every nation a mind of its own; every country will forge alliances and make enemies by themselves, and you can manipulate that with ease to ensure a network of powerful alliances with which to conquer the world. The military system, equally deep and complex, can lead to wars lasting anywhere from merely a single year to several decades. Use technology to outmatch your opponents, and defeat them with a vastly superior army, or expand as much as possible and defeat everyone with sheer numbers.This game, essentially, is the definitive strategy game. Watch as the world changes and as empires form from nothing. Build your own empire and stop all the others. There is infinite replayability; a game will never end the same way twice; Steam achievements give a reason to try many different countries, learn several strategies, and conquer the world ten times over; multiplayer adds an extra layer of madness, allowing you to conquer the world with your friends, only to have them betray you later. There is no good reason for anyone interested in history or strategy games to not buy this one; it is, in a way, the perfect strategy game. The expansions only make it moreso, but add an entirely new system to learn. Even without these expansions, however, there is an almost endless supply of extra content available for free, right here on Steam. With mods, this game can become new again, even for a seasoned veteran of 3000 hours.If I have only one complaint of this game, it is the multiplayer community, and even then the game is not at fault for this. Too often, people will host games and simply boot anyone they don't want, or else make up some sad story to convince people to leave on their own. There is a very simple way to prevent people you don't want to play with from entering your game: put a password on it, and share it with people you do want to play with. This problem leads to another: the lack of a good supply of people with whom to play online multiplayer. Every once in a while, a good person will come along and allow everyone to play with him. These people are, unfortunately, rare, but when they do come along the experience is almost always a great one. There are some synchronization problems with multiplayer, as well, but any game as large as this, when hosting several people at once, is sure to have these, so again I cannot fault this game specifically for that. There will be bugs; it is difficult, after all, to solve every single problem when there is so much code to check; but when there is a problem that the developers have not found, once it is found and reported it is usually corrected soon after.I therefore conclude that this is one of the best games of all time. I can highly recommend buying it, even at full price, and I would rarely advise buying something at full price.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												One of the very best grand strategy games out there. If you have a thirst for world domination and do not like people to tell you how to get there, then this game is for you! You get so many avenues of approach it will become a whole thesis just to list them all. It's about building your country, keeping your friends close and enemies closer, its about building up your army and staying ahead in technology, so that your armies get that edge they deserve! Its about the buildup to the perfect coup de gras. One thing this game does well if to present choices without dumming down the mechanics, in fact it is my experience that with new expansions they ad or expand on gamemechanics making the game more and more immersive, and thus giving the player even more ways to move ahead. This means however that the game has a steep learning curve for new players. You can expect to spend the first 10 or so hours to get a good grip of the basics and still have trouble beating your larger neighours. But the satifaction when you first manage to take down France is immense!To help you, there is a very good and fleshed out wikipage, that for the most part gets updated almost instantly after new expansions gets released.For me, and this is the reason ive reached this many hours on the game, is multiplayer. Going into multiplayer with friends or finding players through the paradox forums, will add a whole new game experience to the mix. Every area of the game gets improved, war, diplomacy etc. The multiplayer part does have a few problems though, as with most paradox games, the game can get unstable after a while, and out of sync problems can and will happen. Slower computers or computers with unstable or slow internetconnection will also present a problem, but can for the most part be solved with slowing down gametime.I recommend this game because there are so many fun hours to be had. Because the way you want to play it, is entirely left up to the player, and because Paradox seens genuinly interested in improving upon this game with its now many expansions.

												This game is fun. Start out small.Conquer some countries. Get rich. Get a gigantic coalition against you.Lose game.Repeat.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~For all of the people swayed by the amount of DLC in the game that you can buy, note that you do not have to buy it in order to enjoy this game. For about a good 300 hours I played this game with no DLC and only then I bought 1 after. The DLC enhances and further immerses you into the game. The game is complex, and has a huge depth. Even after 1K hours, I still don't know how to  conquer the world yet lol. This game will make you frustrated, angry, sad, happy, and narcissistic. I definitely reccomend this game to those who like grand strategy, conquering, and those who are into history.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
GameplayIn a few words: The game is great!In a long story: The game is great, first when i bought this game i though oh well, this is going to be easy to play. I have played the older EU games and the total war series... Man was i wrong when i thought that.Firstly i played the tutorial, i'm someone that always plays it no matter what game, well the tutorial itself was already hard because the whole UI was different, after a few hours i got the UI in my head. So yeah that was a piece of cake.The game itself was really hard for me, i was so used to the total war series and its warfare and diplomacy.After a long time reading the EU4 wiki i began to understand how the game worked. Diplomacy was not like just doing it you had to think ahead in time.Warfare was different too like a siege, you just need a general to get a better siege, also attacking the stronghold while the walls were still standing was a bad idea. Well i learned that.Best of all you can pick all the countries, this gave me so much freedom that i sometimes still abuse till this very day.Even passing through any new reforms, and new technologies really feel like they do something to your country as a whole and its people.The game itself doesn't provide any turnbased gameplay, no it's all realtime even the multiplayer.You think you can be powerfull as Germany, France, England or Russia or any other country? Well forget it, if you're too agressive other countries will go in a pact against you, i mean come on man the AI feels so smart in this game, yes sometimes it's bad but hey it's a game.ModdingAfter playing this game for a while i wanted some different gameplay so i installed mods, like the Extended Timeline Mod, which really recommend, but only after you've played the original game first!After installing some music, graphical and other mods that change gameplay, the game felt even more differently!ImmersiveDon't get me wrong, this game is not immersive like Battlefield, Call of Duty or Red Orchestra (2).This game is more immersive like you're really feeling that you belong to the country and it's "digital" people. If something happens in your land that has any influence to your land and its people you really have the feeling to do something about it, well you better do it otherwise you get ♥♥♥♥ed in the **** later on.But i mean, man my country is devided by its religion, the other side is catholic. Meanwhile the protestant part wants a reform. Netherlands! ^^.Even forming the Netherlands as Utrecht in IronMan mode was a ♥♥♥♥♥, i had luck  that France was willing to help me fight against Burgundy. Even though if the king died i would have to face Austria.Yes the game can be confusing, but also very very simplistic.So many shiny buttons yet so few.OverallI recommend this game to anyone even you haven't played any EU series, i promise you this game provides a totally different gameplay then most other strategy games.This game is a grand stratagy game not just any ordinary strategy game. so what are you waiting for!start throwing money at your screen, just freaking now. Come on ******* NOW!!!

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Otherwise known as "The Map Game".  Simply brilliant.  Forget the razzle dazzle of tactical combat.  You buy other games for that.  Combat here may be considerably more complex in fact than anything you may have played before, but its not flashy.  This is an empire game.  This is a What If game.  This is a choose your own goal and play game.  This is coop or PvP.  The designers are constantly rebalancing and adding new elements.  It may be a couple more YEARS before they let it go and do something else.  So yes even if you master it gameplay wise it changes again.  It strives for realism, and provides a barebones political RPG experience.  Its hard, but hardly impossible.  It constantly teaches you new things, forces you to see your own errors, provides a list of achievements that you really want to attempt.  There's numerous things to do.  Colonize.  War,  Master the Seas.  Establish a trade empire.  Rewrite history.  Screw with politics.  Focus on some things ignore others.  Try to do it all.Try to take over the entire world.  Why haven't you bought this yet ?

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												OK, serious review time.After nearly 900 hours of playing this game, I believe it's appropriate for me to leave an actual, serious review. So this game takes place from 1444 to 1821, so the Renaissance to post Napoleonic Wars, which is a big span of history. You play as a nation trying to find your place in the sun, aspriring to empire-dom and to position you and your nation in the annals of history. You could play as the historical big boys like Castile, Portugal, France, Russia, the Ottomans, etc.Or you could start small. And dream big.This is where the game truly shines. Building yourself up, conquering everyone and everything around you. Sending your people across the seas to build a new home. Constructing the finest army and navy the world has ever seen. Amass a trade empire, steal wealth from your rivals or cleaverly place your merchants in prime cities and ports. Develop your provinces to squeeze as much money, resources and manpower as possible. Build buildings to assist you on your quest to glory, like barracks to improve manpower, marketplaces to squeeze trade out of important provinces or build temples to tax your people more efficiently. Choose idea groups that boost the stats of your nation, like Religious for converting heathen and heretic alike, Quality for easy and quick wars and so on. So what are you waiting for? Pick up a copy and play this beautiful game of grand strategy and conquest. See you at 1000 hours.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Europa Universalis IV is a game of staggering depth end endless possiblities. Almost like an RPG for entire nations. You may lead an obscure country through the centuries from humble beginnings during the late middle ages to greatness and world domination in modern times. But beware! Enemies are unforgiving and will remember your transgressions for a very long time. So tread carefully, chose your friends and enemies wisely and make your choices with diligence and care!Will you be able to save Byzantinium from the Ottoman onslaught? Can you recreate the Colonial Empires of Spain and Portugal? Reunite Germany or Italy? Save the Aztecs from Western aggression? Maintain the independence of Imperial China or Japan? Let your nation triumph over history or see mighty Empires crumble under the weight of your mistakes! Send forth your armies, your explorers, your diplomats, your merchants or your colonists! Be a peaceful nation builder or an aggressive conqueror. All paths can lead to greatness or defeat. The choice is yours!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												I love this game.I didn't think I'd like it.  I didn't expect to try to play it for more then an hour really.   I tried the EU3 demo and gave up after 45 minutes, which is a pretty fair try.  I went into this with low expectations. Some previous games from this publisher have been overly complex messes.  Terrible UI, terrible tutorials, terrible new user experiences, and dry dry dry.   So, I kinda expected the worst here.  However, after a week of playing this a lot, I think this is a great game, and also an enormous accomplishment on the part of it's team, in realizing a vision so counter to conventional wisdom, and so compelling.  The tutorials are not great, but they are enough to get you started.  You have to want to play this, to get over the new user hump.  This game has zero pick-up-and-play appeal for new players, which is why I'm taking the time to write this, because it's so worth it, once you spend that time to learn to play.  Where the tutorials let the new player down, youtube fills the gap.  There are hundreds of short tutorial videos on various topics and mechanics to fill you in.  There's also a great wiki, and a very active forum.  I'm no apologist for bad design choices, but I do appreciate the enormity of the task the team faced in trying to teach this game.  It's big.EUIV is big.   Really really big.   You may think Civ is big, but that's only because you have no idea just how big EUIV is.   What makes this game so addictive is that it has the same turn based appeal of a Civ game, but without turns.  As a player, you have dozens of things to care about (or not care about, it's really up to you, you set your own win criteria in this sandbox), and they will all overlap, and play out simultaneously.  An example:In Guantanamo (Eastern Cuba) Particularist rebels were sieging my government.  They demanded a local tax break, but to give in would drop my Empire's prestige.  That prestige matters, because maintaining it helps my regime’s legitimacy, trade power, military morale, and allows me to develop good relations with other states faster.  So, giving in and giving away a tax break in a little corner of Cuba of little value to me is actually a very bad thing.  So, I needed an army to crush them.  Unfortunately, I only had about 3000 soldiers in Cuba, so I started recruiting more in Havana asap.  Along the eastern seaboard I did have some significant forces, but I was leary of withdrawing too many lest the Spanish or the Cree or the Algonquin decide my New England colonies were under defended.  I started moving troops south regardless, though in small number, while simultaneously recruiting the replacements.   These rebels had to be put down quickly, if they tool the provincial capital, it would likely result in a stability drop for my empire.  Stability, like legitimacy, is a stat with huge effects (taxes, revolt risk, trade power, espionage defence, and legitimacy are all touched by it).However, building up forces quickly in the Americas was hampered by my low manpower pool.   I had been busy fighting three other wars at the same time, and it's been bleeding my manpower reserves for the past 15 years or so.   One war was straightforward colonial aggression.  I had been crushing the small states in what's today called India, making them vessels, and demanding trade concessions on and off for the past 80 years.   Things were going well for me, but that war had recently expanded as Deli led a coalition against me.  Militarily it wasn't trouble, as my tech was vastly superior, but in some of my previously conquered provinces the people were rebelling, and I didn't have enough boots on the ground to simultaneously put them all down.  Still, it was manageable, I had my navy and I was still able to starve them into submission.  Being able to maintain this navy was proving difficult however, as I was also fighting two wars in the Mediterranean.  One was a conflict between Hungary and the Papal State over some province one of them wanted from the other, I don’t really know or care what that was about, but Hungary was my alley and rather than suffer a loss of prestige I backed them.  Turns out that may have been a bad move, since Spain them jumped in on the other side.  I should have seen that coming, as I had just badly snubbed Spain by winning over one of their bishops by supporting him as a future cardinal, and they were still sore.  Still, the real trouble came as Naples and Savoy picked a fight with my Milan, who was holding Corsica.  This one mattered to me because I've been paying the Milanese for the past 60 odd years for rights to base my fleet there, and I didn't want to loose the port.  So, that meant calling my allies in to help, as I was getting stretched a bit thin.  Aaragon gamely stepped up and tried to hold Corsica.   I built up a huge new fleet in the Americas, and then took it to the Med, where I basically closed every hostile port till we could come to terms.  In India, I dictated a peace.  The terms were not what I was quite after, but long term it's a win.  rather then take any land, I broke up several powerful states into many weak ones.  I was a liberator!  Welcome to independence Bastar, Garjat, Kalingandhra and Bijapur!  I will enjoy our future together.  Of the Hungarian problem, I chose to give the other side whatever they were after, ♥♥♥♥ Hungary, they shouldn't have started it.  In Cuba, about 30 minutes later and after having lost two provinces, for a time, I eventually crushed the rebels.   So, the thing about this game is that all of these threads play out simultaneously.   Above I’m describing some of what was going on over a one hour span, but those are just the main points.  I was also developing trade in England, consolidating my hold on Gibraltar, colonizing Australia and Exploring the Chinese coast.  You are constantly pausing the sim and making adjustments, popping about the globe, laying plans, making a constant stream of decisions, and IT NEVER ENDS.   There's never a good moment to pause, because there's always 5 important things going on.   Yes, the learning curve is silly steep, but it's totally worth it.James

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												I wrote a massive review for Crusader Kings II, but it was too long, and the TL;DR was just to buy the game. The exact same can be said about Europa Universalis IV, it is just historical strategy goodness. The soundtrack, while not as strong as CK2's, is still fantastic (especially that main theme), there are thousands of nations to play, each playing differently than the next, and the devs love to add free contect with every update. The gameplay is phenominal. The tutorial is much better than it was in CK2, and actually teaches the player the basics of the game, while letting them discover things on there own. It takes less than an hour to learn, and you don't even have to use external guides! This is by far the most accessable Paradox title to date. The mods for this game also add so much, from just a simple graphic modification to complete game overhauls. The mods add so much to the game. Honestly, I can go on for hours about this game, but I am not going to. Just get it, and enjoy one of my favorite games of all time.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
GameplayIn a few words: The game is great!In a long story: The game is great, first when i bought this game i though oh well, this is going to be easy to play. I have played the older EU games and the total war series... Man was i wrong when i thought that.Firstly i played the tutorial, i'm someone that always plays it no matter what game, well the tutorial itself was already hard because the whole UI was different, after a few hours i got the UI in my head. So yeah that was a piece of cake.The game itself was really hard for me, i was so used to the total war series and its warfare and diplomacy.After a long time reading the EU4 wiki i began to understand how the game worked. Diplomacy was not like just doing it you had to think ahead in time.Warfare was different too like a siege, you just need a general to get a better siege, also attacking the stronghold while the walls were still standing was a bad idea. Well i learned that.Best of all you can pick all the countries, this gave me so much freedom that i sometimes still abuse till this very day.Even passing through any new reforms, and new technologies really feel like they do something to your country as a whole and its people.The game itself doesn't provide any turnbased gameplay, no it's all realtime even the multiplayer.You think you can be powerfull as Germany, France, England or Russia or any other country? Well forget it, if you're too agressive other countries will go in a pact against you, i mean come on man the AI feels so smart in this game, yes sometimes it's bad but hey it's a game.ModdingAfter playing this game for a while i wanted some different gameplay so i installed mods, like the Extended Timeline Mod, which really recommend, but only after you've played the original game first!After installing some music, graphical and other mods that change gameplay, the game felt even more differently!ImmersiveDon't get me wrong, this game is not immersive like Battlefield, Call of Duty or Red Orchestra (2).This game is more immersive like you're really feeling that you belong to the country and it's "digital" people. If something happens in your land that has any influence to your land and its people you really have the feeling to do something about it, well you better do it otherwise you get ♥♥♥♥ed in the **** later on.But i mean, man my country is devided by its religion, the other side is catholic. Meanwhile the protestant part wants a reform. Netherlands! ^^.Even forming the Netherlands as Utrecht in IronMan mode was a ♥♥♥♥♥, i had luck  that France was willing to help me fight against Burgundy. Even though if the king died i would have to face Austria.Yes the game can be confusing, but also very very simplistic.So many shiny buttons yet so few.OverallI recommend this game to anyone even you haven't played any EU series, i promise you this game provides a totally different gameplay then most other strategy games.This game is a grand stratagy game not just any ordinary strategy game. so what are you waiting for!start throwing money at your screen, just freaking now. Come on ******* NOW!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												tl;dr: Great game, lots of detail and depth, people attacking DLC policy ignore the fact that the base game is perfectly fine on its own and purchasers are not being cheated.Dear Reader,Please take the reviews bashing Paradox for their DLC policy with a grain of salt. Paradox is not cheating buyers, nor have they cut up the game and sold it in pieces, or in any way "forced" players to buy it. The game was released in 2013, and since then has seen a constant stream of updates, patches and improvements. Many of the new features and all of the patches are free. While I concede that the game has a great deal of DLC and many of them are overpriced (when not on sale, at least), Paradox has continually improved the game even for people who don't buy the DLC. I reccomend trying the vanilla game and getting the most critical DLC (Art of War, Common Sense, Cossacks, Rights of Man) on sale if you like what you've seen. While some of the features of the DLC are extremely useful, the game is not broken without them, and they are not necessary to play.On to the game itself:Europa Universalis IV is an amazingly detailed grand strategy game, and one of the best games I have ever played. Its diplomacy, warfare and economics are incredibly detailed and diverse. Variations in country attributes, religions, geography and government give the game near-infinite replayability (for me at least), and the ability to customize your nation and choose it's path means you can create anything from a globe-spanning colonial trade republic to a strictly authoritarian monarchy with an unbeatable military. I strongly reccomend the game to anyone with the slightest interest in strategy.The devs are friendly, communicative and take player feedback. Nearly all issues that players bring up are dealt with, and devs are active in conversations on the Paradox Forums. The community is also friendly and reasonably large. Multiplayer games are common and the subreddit and forums can usually answer any questions you have. Just watch out for the memes.While the price tag can be imposing, the game regularly goes 75% off. DLC can also be found regularly for 75% or 66% off.Just to let everyone know what they are getting in to: when I say this game has depth, I mean DEPTH. While this is great for creating intrest, realism and replay value, it also means the game can be complicated and confusing to start. This is NOT a game where you can click around and easily figure things out for yourself; I would reccomend any starting player to find a friend who already knows the game to explain it to you. Starting will probably require an hour-long explanation that will leave your head spinning, but after you get started, the game provides hundreds of hours of challenges and fun. If none of your friends own the game, there are many guides to try to help you get started or understand a certain country, and as mentioned before, the community is large and happy to answer any questions. Just search for the EUIV subreddit or the Paradox Forums.Happy Conquering, Everyone!

												tl;dr: Great game, lots of detail and depth, people attacking DLC policy ignore the fact that the base game is perfectly fine on its own and purchasers are not being cheated.Dear Reader,Please take the reviews bashing Paradox for their DLC policy with a grain of salt. Paradox is not cheating buyers, nor have they cut up the game and sold it in pieces, or in any way "forced" players to buy it. The game was released in 2013, and since then has seen a constant stream of updates, patches and improvements. Many of the new features and all of the patches are free. While I concede that the game has a great deal of DLC and many of them are overpriced (when not on sale, at least), Paradox has continually improved the game even for people who don't buy the DLC. I reccomend trying the vanilla game and getting the most critical DLC (Art of War, Common Sense, Cossacks, Rights of Man) on sale if you like what you've seen. While some of the features of the DLC are extremely useful, the game is not broken without them, and they are not necessary to play.On to the game itself:Europa Universalis IV is an amazingly detailed grand strategy game, and one of the best games I have ever played. Its diplomacy, warfare and economics are incredibly detailed and diverse. Variations in country attributes, religions, geography and government give the game near-infinite replayability (for me at least), and the ability to customize your nation and choose it's path means you can create anything from a globe-spanning colonial trade republic to a strictly authoritarian monarchy with an unbeatable military. I strongly reccomend the game to anyone with the slightest interest in strategy.The devs are friendly, communicative and take player feedback. Nearly all issues that players bring up are dealt with, and devs are active in conversations on the Paradox Forums. The community is also friendly and reasonably large. Multiplayer games are common and the subreddit and forums can usually answer any questions you have. Just watch out for the memes.While the price tag can be imposing, the game regularly goes 75% off. DLC can also be found regularly for 75% or 66% off.Just to let everyone know what they are getting in to: when I say this game has depth, I mean DEPTH. While this is great for creating intrest, realism and replay value, it also means the game can be complicated and confusing to start. This is NOT a game where you can click around and easily figure things out for yourself; I would reccomend any starting player to find a friend who already knows the game to explain it to you. Starting will probably require an hour-long explanation that will leave your head spinning, but after you get started, the game provides hundreds of hours of challenges and fun. If none of your friends own the game, there are many guides to try to help you get started or understand a certain country, and as mentioned before, the community is large and happy to answer any questions. Just search for the EUIV subreddit or the Paradox Forums.Happy Conquering, Everyone!

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Rewriting the world's history has never been this complex and fun at the same time. If you have ever wondered what would have been if you were in command of the greatest nations of the past, it is your turn to shine. Europa Universalis IV combines fluent gameplay with rich details that allow you to control the tiniest aspect within your empire's borders. On the contrary of all modern games, you will be forced to act strategically instead of going a blind all-out war during your campaigns, as you will clearly understand that no country can be that much of a superpower tyrant when it comes to clear blows but that also doesn't mean you can't lay waste to any smug rivals who dare to cross you. Europa Universalis IV is a gem, underlining that great leaders should always think two steps ahead. Do you think you can be one?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												I have been told multiple times by my friend to buy this fantastic real time strategy game. I took me some time until I was convinced to spend my money on this game, because I was waiting on a sale (This game is totally worth buying full price, however it is frequently on sale).First impressions:I was fortunate enough to have someone experienced, to teach me the game mechanics, because Europa Universalis 4 is very complex games, that requires a lot of time and effort to learn. Personally, it took me around 30 to 50 hours of multiple playthroughs with different countries to completely understand the basics. However now with over 120 hours of having played this game (as of writing this review) I really understand what I am doing.Singleplayer:Personally, I wouldn’t recommend playing singleplayer at first to someone who is new to the game. Look for someone experienced who can teach you the basics first. If you know what you are doing, singleplayer is a great way to relax or if you want a challenge you can start a game in ironman mode. Ironman mode is an optional gameplay feature that restricts control over the saved game, disallowing the player from correcting mistakes and changing decisions made during the course of play. So basically if you screw up you cannot reload a save file.Multiplayer:I find multiplayer the best way to experience the game. Concurring the world with your friends, creating colonial empires, handicapping yourself for example to defeat Europa as an underdeveloped tribe together and many other things, give the game a huge variety.  The game can change form slow pace gameplay, like building an infrastructure to intense battles to defend or conquer land, in an instant. Every new playthrough with your friends, even with the same countries, feels like a new adventure.I personally think playing against real players is the greatest way to enjoy this game. Even though the AI is smart and is being improved constantly it can sometimes be predictable and okaying against Randoms or friends will give you the best experience.Are there any negative aspects to this game?Yes, there are some negative aspects to this game. Some are minor like the steep learning curve and some are rather negative, like needing all the DLCs to fully experience the game and if you really want to get the game with all the DLCs, you will spend easily more than 80€ (As I already said the game and the DLCs are frequently on sale, which cuts the total price more that 60% to around 40€). If you play alone without most of the DLCs the game feels like it is missing some key features. However, this can easily be bypassed if one of your friends already owns the DLCs, because if you play with your friends a multiplayer session and the host owns the DLCs, everyone connected can experience the additional features of the DLCs without paying. That’s a great move by paradox studios.Summary: So, should I buy this game?You defiantly should buy it. I have rarely found strategy games, that had me addicted, saying multiple times a day to myself: “Come on, 5 more minutes are ok! You can go to sleep then”. The complexity of this game is what makes this game so great and addictive to play. Even though the price is expensive, EU4 is frequently on sale cutting its price by around 50-75%. Furthermore, for the beginners I strongly suggest watch tutorials that explain the basics so you don’t feel lost at the beginning. If you are not willing to invest time in learning this is not a game for you.Thank you for reading and I hope you enjoy Europa Universalis 4.This was my first review if you have anything to say, that I can improve for my next review pls do tell me.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												Love, love, love this game. I've always loved games where you can conquer the world, Civ 5 being one of my favorites, but it also felt too simplified for me. But then I found this game, and it is wonderful. EU 4 is easily the closest to real life Conquest Simulation game I've played. And its difficult. This is not an easy game, by any means. There is a TON of stuff going on and many smaller things people don't realize they need. For example you can't just declare war whenever you want (not without a huge penalty anyways) if you want to conquer lands you first need to fabricate a claim on the lands. I would recommend that if you are coming from Civ 5 or something similar you should watch some YouTubers play the game first to get a handle on what you are expected to do, that really helped me. The game is of course not without issues, and I'll give a list of pros and cons below.Pros~ Realistic~ History is of your choosing (You want to conquer the British Isles as Scotland, you can do that. You want Norway to be the first to have colonies in Africa, you can do that, etc...)~ Challenging  ~ Tons of Mods (Basically if its not in Vanilla there is a pretty good chance its a mod)Cons~ World always starts out the same, and usually follows a similar path every time.  ~ All the DLC (I mean $150 for all the DLC, really?)~ Massive Learning Curve (Don't expect to pick up this game and have an empire spanning China to France as you could in Civ 5. At the same time don't give up if you lose a couple wars and lose a good chunk of your empire, its still possible to come back)~ Play throughs feel the same (Due to how the game sets you up, every play-through ends up feeling pretty similar, especially in the beginning. Picking a different nation to start with can change this but you can pretty much predict the first 50 years or so) Edit:So after playing several more games, and playing different countries with different goals, I can say that the same is not as "samey" as it initially felt it to be. Usually each game starts out with similar Alliances and stuff, but after maybe the first 5 years things can get pretty crazy.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												I wrote a massive review for Crusader Kings II, but it was too long, and the TL;DR was just to buy the game. The exact same can be said about Europa Universalis IV, it is just historical strategy goodness. The soundtrack, while not as strong as CK2's, is still fantastic (especially that main theme), there are thousands of nations to play, each playing differently than the next, and the devs love to add free contect with every update. The gameplay is phenominal. The tutorial is much better than it was in CK2, and actually teaches the player the basics of the game, while letting them discover things on there own. It takes less than an hour to learn, and you don't even have to use external guides! This is by far the most accessable Paradox title to date. The mods for this game also add so much, from just a simple graphic modification to complete game overhauls. The mods add so much to the game. Honestly, I can go on for hours about this game, but I am not going to. Just get it, and enjoy one of my favorite games of all time.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												EU-IV is one of the best strategy games in terms of diplomacy and AI. For me, EU-IV is the first Paradox game I've played that is both highly-detailed as well as accessible. Hearts of Iron III, set in a more interesting time period personally, often came up short because the details were interesting but not exactly well-presented or described. And the AI is actually quite competent at determining how weak or strong you are and when to attack.EU-IV's strengths:+ Diplomacy has many, many options+ Single-player is strong because of how well the AI tends to be+ DLC model is not absurd (DLCs add mechanics, features, etc... each nation comes with the base game).+ Replayability is high (especially with the New World DLC or whatever than randomizes the Western Hemisphere).EU-IV's weaknesses:- Still a little obtuse, at times (info isn't always readily at hand or understandable, but better than HoI3).- Music for the base game is very repetative even after just a couple hours (buying music DLC helps, or listening to an I-pod)- Settings for gameplay are nowhere near as detailed as Civ V's (Ironman mode enforces most options, no other maps but the one).- If you managed to learn HoI3 and really enjoyed it, there's the issue of military strategy in this game being a little thread-bare in comparison.The strengths, though, are in much more important areas than the weaknesses. Since I don't play multiplayer, I can't speak to that, although from what I gather the multiplayer tends to have the same flaws of most large strategy games (connection issues, de-syncs, bugs, etc.). But as far as single-player strategy games go, EU-IV is the best in a long time. I truly prefer Total War games because of the way those games combine tactics and strategy, but after the mess that Rome 2 became, I picked up EU-IV and put a good chunk of time into it. So, coming from a Total War player who played HoI3 and was sort of mixed about it because of how badly it sometimes conveyed important information to you, I have to say, EU-IV is a phenomenal game. Really, despite it not being my normal style, I have to say EU-IV is fantastic. It's just the right mixture of simplicity (Crusader Kings 2 was ultimately too simplistic for me outside of the personality traits and all the characters in your kingdoms) and complexity (HoI3 was highly detailed, but sometimes lost cohesion because of this). I'd recommend EU-IV any day, and right now (11/28/2014, Black Friday), it's $9.99.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												In all of Paradox Entertainment's vast arsenal of historical "strategy/simulation" games, Europa Universalis has always had a special place in my heart.The attention to detail is fantastic. What one would dismiss as simple flavor (unit graphics, etc.) is actually an integral part of EU IV, the latest game using the Clausewitz engine, which basically freed this genre from its old horrible graphics. The GUI could use a little bit more work, and it's as clunky as it has always been with Paradox games, but it does the job well and there are major improvements nonetheless.Historical accuracy is also fascinating, although one could have some problems with how some historical events are translated into the game's language (modifiers, rewards, etc. sometimes may not exactly reflect the impact some of these events had in the history of the Empire that the player chooses to play.It still is a fascinating piece of art, with an engaging gameplay that can glue one to the chair for hours end. The "just one more turn!" effect of the Civilization series translates here to "just one more year until I save and quit".The music has improved so much since the older days of the franchise.10/10, would buy again.

content:
Posted: April 20
												Good Game but the DLC practices are ♥♥♥♥ing rediculous.  New updates rely on your ability to use features that are locked behind the paywall of one of the 1000's of DLCs they have released, and for new players, good luck finding which ones have the features you need.  Base game in itself is enjoyable and fleshed out enough to get 100's of hours of play from.  A single playthrough can take 20 hours or more if you go slow and pause frequently so be prepared to dedicate a ton of time sitting watching manpower recover and provinces getting cored.  Unless you have a lot of cash to throw around.  Stick to base game and load a prior release version of the game where DLC isn't required to be effective and efficient.Edit: Also, if you want your head to elplode, click show all DLC button and realize the cost of all DLC for the game is 7 times the cost of the base game and the total price for this one game and its DLC is over 300$

content:
Posted: October 7, 2013
												欧陆风云四是一款天体太空模拟类游戏作为玩家，你需要随时随地与各种外来不明飞行物体进行对抗游戏开发商称之为“扫帚星”相比于普通的彗星来说，这种扫帚星的可怕之处在于一旦它们经过地球上空，那么你的国家的子民就会产生极大的恐慌然后民心不安、政局动荡、甚至于国家分崩离析。更可怕的是，这种扫帚星是完全不能被预测的，在带来如此重大危害的同时，却只会被你的子民所看到，你的敌人会对它视而不见。想想看，在强敌环伺之时来一颗甚至成群的不明飞行物是多么有挑战性的一件事啊，所以欧陆风云四对于那些天体爱好者来说一定是一个非常棒的选择。————————以上~是开玩笑————————欧陆风云四和前作的主题一样，都是选择1444-1820之间的一个国家，然后操纵它一直玩到游戏结束，整个游戏围绕着外交、贸易、殖民、建设、战争、以及各种丰富的随机事件进行（就像之前所说的慧星划过天空事件、、、）欧陆风云四总得来说比起前作，画面精致了很多可操作和需要考虑的地方也多了很多，当然，限制也多了很多，和前作比起来，它更加贴近真实就像Paradox所宣称的那样，我们做欧陆风云4，就是要让游戏自动运行的情况下重演历史对于历史控很有吸引力，虽然对欧洲以外的国家设定非常偏颇一些想玩东亚国家的人会在初期受挫，不过这个游戏的MOD众多，并且有一大批玩家正在不断地制作新的MOD（我就做过一个不过后来半途而废了、、、）画面质量：★★★游戏乐趣：★★★耐玩程度：★★★★★上手速度：★更多可能：★★★★

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												_Game information_I'll be reviewing this game as someone who hasn't played the previous games that much. I've played 1-2h of EU3 while waiting to buy EU4.As of writing this I've played 179h of EU4 and just now finished one game in Ironman mode (saves every month and you can't go back nor cheat). Around 100h of the 179h I've played that one game as Sweden where I own Sweden, Finland, Denmark, Iceland, Mexico and a lot of provinces of east europe including provinces from Finland to Kazakstan, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and also own provinces around Hamburg in Germanic territory.The game starts at 1440 AD and ends at 1820 AD. You get to choose countries from all over the world to play as and every country has it's own ideas and special events. Meaning that no country is the same as any other.In 1440 AD in North America you have a few natives, including Aztec which are very low tech. In Europe there's a lot of small countries within the germanic region under something called the Holy Roman Empire. A closenit group of countries together with a leading country (starting with Austria in 1440 AD) where the emperor may defend the countries within the Holy Roman Empire. Spain is divided into four countries, Castile, Aragon (where Aragon owns the east side of Spain), Granada (Four provinces South-East of Spain) and Navarra (Small state at the top border between Castile and Aragon).Now, the game is about getting your country to be the best country in the world. You can make your own goals about what you want to do. Conquer the world, become the great power, colonize a continent or form a specific country. If you want to conquer the world you can't just declare war on everybody and take over their provinces, you get penalties for conquering provinces: overextension, aggressive expansion and province penalites like wrong religion and culture group. There's a lot of diplomatic thoughts going into the game and it's supposed to have some real-life mechanics. This is something that Civilization serie doesn't have. A lot of stuff in Civ is independent and you can't any benefits from being behind or penalties from behind far ahead. Civ5 is very flawed when it comes to the diplomacy. The easiest way to win there is by war. In EU4 the easiest way to win is by a good balance between everything depending on the country you're playing as. If you want to declare a war in EU4 you most surely want a Casus Belli. A reason to declare war on a country. Be it for a trade dispute, or conquest. If you don't have a Casus Belli you will suffer a stability cost in your country (stability goes from -3 to +3 and gives a lot of bonuses to you if it's positive). If you have a truce with a country you get a higher stability cost and if there's no Casus Belli they stack. So you can go from +3 to -3 stability if you're doing a dumb move. That alone has cause you to lost a lot of benefits and started to get penalties, revolt risk and a lot of wasted administration points (which you can use to boost your stability. admin. points is mentioned below)You need to have advisors to get special benefits for trade, production, diplomatic reputation and military bonuses. There's also administration, diplomatic and military points which you have to spend on idea groups and technologies. Administration takes care of coring provinces, which reduces overextension, and improving stability. Diplomatic takes care of changing culture groups, reducing war exhaustion and is used to do multiple things in working out an agreement in a war (like taking multiple provinces). Military can be used for harsh treatment to lower revolt risk in certain provinces or to get forced march on your regiments. The points may also be used for building improvements on your provinces. Using up admin., diplo. or military points for certain improvements. Every improvement is different and every province has a different base tax.There's a lot more to the game, there's a trade system, honoring wars, vassalization and there's terra incognita (places you can't yet see in the world). So the game itself has a very harsh learning curve. But some countries are easier to play than others which makes it easier for new players to jump in and learn it without getting run over too much.As I've played 179h of the game for multiple small games and one big game one should think I'm bored. Yet there's so much stuff to do in the game. No country can survive on their own and you need alliances to survive. I will continue to try and play as many interesting countries as I can and see if I can conquer the world or see if I can take care of taking certain continents or taking europe as american natives (like Aztecs)._Sounds_The sounds effects in the game fits in very well and the music as well. You can definitely play for whole day without getting tired of the music or sound effects. Although, the more you play the move the music becomes repetive. I would've liked if they added a bunch more songs that plays._It's not all amazing_There are some issues, that's for sure. The game doesn't display some things and you have to calculate it by looking at the country or looking up equations on the wiki or how the game calculates some stuff. It could've definitely displayed a lot more information somewhere just to make it easier to play the game. And just like most games with player vs. AI the AI has the upper hand. If someone declares war and wants you to join them in a war, you can choose to join or not to join. By not joining you get a -25 prestige penalty and a -5 distrust with some countries. But if you declare war on someone and they won't join you they won't get that penalty. Likewise other stuff. You can't try and buy provinces from other countries but you can sell them. There's a lot more I can't think out on the top off my head but they are not game breaking. It's just small issues that I would've liked to be fixed.When a country declares war on someone else you can't easily see why they declared war or other information about it. You can't see how the war turned out when it ended but you have to look in logs to see if you can find it (which may take forever as a lot of stuff happen in the log).The bugs in the game are almost non existant though. There's one I keep getting from time to time is during the peace offer window if you select the vassal country option the game may just close. But the devs keep updating the game so it might've get fixed in the last update or so._Summary_EU4 is a good strategy game that runs on a speed based system. You have speeds from 1-5 and can pause the game to do stuff while being paused. There's a lot of mechanics in the game for doing certain things like declaring war and gaining the war goal or to get trade power in a trade node. Albeing the game has some issues with not being able to display some things and having some equations that you need to guess yourself up to know what it is and so you know what you need to reach to get a certain value. The wiki is your big help and so is the steam community posts. There may be things like you can't conquer a certain province but it won't tell you why and stuff like that.But all in all, there's a lot of good elements in the game and you can play however you want and get big in some way or another. If you feel like playing a good strategy game with a lot of elements to it with semi-realistic diplomatic systems you should definitely pick it up as you may spend as much time as I have to play the game.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This is one of the greatest grand strategy games out there along with CK2. Basically you pick any country (that exists) in the world from near the end of the Middle Ages in 1444 A.D. to 1821 A.D. at the end of the Napoleonic age and you play them until the game ends at 1821. Everything is historically based and of course there are hundreds of countries to pick from meaning you'll spend hours and hours of this game just playing a new and different country each time. Each game length varies, but I'd say at least a full twenty four hours each if you really immerse yourself. Every single experience for each country is not the same, as most countries have unique ideas that affect the way you play each country, and they all aren't equally powerful, meaning different approaches and strategies have to be used in order to be successful. Want to change history? You could save Constantinople from the Turks and restore the Roman Empire, or you could even take over Britain as Ireland. The possibilities are endless. Downsides? Not much, however the game and UI can be overwhelming to some at first.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												If you're a light-strategy gamer, I wouldn't recommend this game to you unless you know what you're up against here.Prior to buying this game, I was an avid Civ V (a turn based, relatively simple strategy game). I now understand just how simple Civ V is compared to this game. It's extremely indepth, you practically choose what your citizens eat for dinner*. If you're a hardcore strategy gamer, this game is possibly one of the best you can find in the store, offering a wide range of abilities to any player.Based in the renaissance era, you can control any country within Eurasia, North America, Central America and even some of Africa and the Middle East. Most of these countries are thoroughly fleshed out, offering different kinds of gameplay depending on whom you border etc. Specific areas of history allow the player to change the course entirely. For instance, the British can defeat the Americans in the War of Independence, or the French Royalists can defeat the Republicans. It's totally up to you.Do not go into this game thinking it has some sort of Total War battles, as it's very different. The success of battles are dependant on the morale of your troops, numbers, terrain, defenses. Over time the enemy (or you!) will be worn down and eventually rout. It's a very different system that contrasts nicely with the standard Total War battle system that I'm so used to.In summary, this game is extremely bloody complicated! But so damn good!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												I would overall describe Europa Universalis 4 as a deeply engaging strategy game, rich in detail, with complex and intelligently designed game mechanics, and boasting a high degree of replayability. It is well deserving of the title Grand Strategy Game, both in terms of the sheer time invested in a single playthrough, in terms of depth of gameplay, the strategic elements, and the amount of freedom you as a player has to take your nation in different directions either through military conquest, exploration, diplomacy or trade.You start out in 1444 playing as one of the world's roughly 300 (?) starting nations (although the colloquial term 'nation' might not be entirely appropriate here, since you can also play as a variety of american and meso-american indian tribes, central asian nomadic steppe hordes, and so on). The game runs in real time all the way to 1820, which takes a while to get to even with the game running at highest speed (my recent Great Britain campaign gave me roughly two weeks solid of gameplay, although my gamepace may be quite slow compared to the young and healthy gamers of today). In the allotted space of time that consists the Early Modern Period in history you are free to decide whether you want to expand your nation's borders through conquest (perhaps playing as one of the superpowers of the day like France, Austria, England or the Ottomans), or explore the world with ships and eventually colonizing parts of it, or whether you want to pick a more peaceful route as a small but wealthy merchant state, play a tactical diplomacy game or just trying to survive as as a small nation and perhaps one day even growing into a superpower yourself. The game in short offers a lot of variability in playstyle, and also a lot of entertainment for the counterfactual history nerds out there (what do you mean Norway didn't colonize California and Hawaii in the 1600s?)Having not played any earlier iterations of the game (I am somewhat familiar with Hearts of Iron 3, another of Paradox's flagship titles) I feel as if I picked the very best time to enter into this series. Not only is it Paradox's most polished and well-designed games to date, it is also the game that seems to have brought them to a much broader (if perhaps not exactly a mainstream) audience. While I am ill placed to give a detailed comparison of EU4's gameplay to the gameplay of earlier titles, it does seem that this is the first time they've managed to combine all the gameplay elements in such a well-designed, overall consistent and appealing package. The game is by no means easy to get into for the uninitiated to deep strategy games (and it doesn't help that the tutorial feels a bit lackluster), but once you get an understanding of the basic elements of play it quickly draws you in - even if all of the possible strategic decisions you can make in the interest of your nation's welfare may seem overwhelming at first. In summary, I would heartily recommend EU4 to anyone interested in strategy games of any sort, and especially if you appreciate complex gameplay and strategic decision making over graphic fidelity and fast-paced action.A final warning/disclaimer: There is a danger of turning autistic from playing this game. If you are susceptible to forgetting basic necessities in life because you are busy crunching numbers, turning dials, figuring out army composition ratios and all in all paying extraordinary amounts of attention to very minute details, then this game may not be for you.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Probably one of the best games ever released. Please mind that you need to spend ATLEAST 15-20 hours before this game actually becomes enjoyable, trust me. The learning curve is pretty steep and you'll struggle to understand anything at all the first few hours. If you have a friend playing, force him to help you. If you don't, check out the EU4 Wikis. But when you learn how to brutaly conquer your neighbouring nations, it will be worth it. You'll look back and suddenly realize why you that one time lost all your stability, because you declared war on your own vassal. I do think this game is for everyone, if they just take their time to learn it. But will mostly apeel to people who are somewhat interested in history. Despite a bunch of bugs leading to several game crashes since the Art of War patch (Which are mostly fixed by now), this is probably one of the most polished and well developed game out there. The historical accuracy is on point, the cheer amount of playable nations is insane and there is just SO much to do, almost every nation is unique in atleast some ways and you'll face different problems as each one of them.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												I love Europa Universalis IV, I really do, so not being able to recommend it pains me. But the cost of this game is just ballooning to ridiculous heights. I don't mind all the cosmetic DLC. I didn't the cost of content DLC, when they were reasonably priced and added significantly to the scope of the game. But I can't accept paying $15-$20 every few months for incremental changes.At this point I haven't played the game for months. I keep holding out on playing it, hoping the costs of the last few DLC will drop to sane levels so I can purchase them and have a proper gameplay experience that'll mesh well with the free updates. But I'm finally realizing this is ridiculous. I love EUIV, but it's not worth this stress. I have better things to spend my money on than mediocre updates that cost half of what I spent on the whole game itself.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												It is a very interesting game. It adds new perspectives according to the country that you wish to play.Pros:+ Beautiful images and world map details;+ Different locations, starting places and in game events make every game a complete different experience. I started as Spain and got a big rival as England, then I tried Spain again and got the Otomans at my door;+ There are various in game tools and elements that allow you to grow, research, make money, run politics, royal marriages, alliances, wars and sabotage among others.Cons:- Every move counts, so wrong moves or waiting too much can allow your enemies to make alliances or declare war against you;- Winning wars count more if you lead the alliance, it doesn't matter if you took territories and won all the battles, the leading country decides how to split the loot based on their perspective;- Some borders or fronteirs for larger countries are not real state or province borders, perhaps it was for in game  balance but I would love to see more real borders.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												I have really enjoyed my time playing this game. I particularly enjoy the nation builder and creating fun optimized if weirdly located nations and then seeing if I can get them big enough to compete with the already established powers in a few hundred years. Its well balanced, tons of options, great events, every game is completely different even if you play the same nation with the same settings. The combat is a little boring on a battle scale but better having to manage it globally. Same with ships for trading/fighting - you either have superior numbers/troops/general and you win or you dont and you lose. The best feature of this game is that its from Paradox... and they update/improve their games constantly as they release new content packs. The game is VERY different from its origianl version and has gotten better almost every step of the way. Its very easy to spend 40-60 hours on a playthrough without noticing the time go by. Hope you enjoy it as well.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												After finishing my first real Europa game, I can say without reservation that this is hands-down the best grand strategy game ever made.Europa is a game without any true victory goals, the fate and future of your people rests in your hands. Will you become defender of your faith and declare war on the heretics and heathens? Will you enter the slave trade? Will you colonize? Will you attempt to conquer the world? Will you survive the test of time?Albeit difficult to master and even harder to pick up and play, it's richly rewarding and incredibly fun. If you thought "just one more turn" was bad in Civ, just wait till you get caught up in committing genocide! You'll be up until the wee hours of the morning for certain.https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUoTkKw8Mb8ZQp666F3ZdCkaeHQSxFG7xIf you decide to pick Europa up, a viewing of this tutorial series is highly recommended.
