number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Europa Universalis IV is a game I've enjoy greatly when I have the time to play it. And if you're like me then you can't just play it for 1 hour but you keep playing it for quite a while. This means that you'll need plenty of free time on your hands when you start. That said I do recognise that this game might bore some people as you'll need to set goals for yourself or that you sometimes need to wait until some particular date before you can undergo a big action. Patience can be quite the virtue in this game as you wait until your relations with your allies are good enough before you start a war. This is a grand strategy game which means that it is quite complex but paradox has done a good job showing you the most necessary things to just do well in the game. To be great some research is required but you can start with the basic and learn some things by just trying them out in game.I like to compare this game to the total war games but where total war focusses more on combat this one focusses more on the politics. You can't just declare war at someone and hope you'll be okay, you'll need a cause for war (Casus belli) or forge one. Different to the total war series, this doesn't have real time combat. This makes your AI opponents tougher in war as you can't misuse some combat mechanics. You can however be quite lucky and still win a losing battle. An other difference is that the game doesn't work with turns, time will pass by and you can adjust how fast or slow (or eve pause it)Now, about the map. The map is a map of everything your nation knows about the world. Thus when playing China you won't even know that Europe exists. You can however discover it as the game progresses. There is a lot of modes in which you can see the map. Depending on the mode the map shows different information. One example of such a mode is the religious mode. with the religious you can see which religions are nearby and which don't belong to the religion of the country the area belongs to. When selecting the Trade mode you can see the flow of trade. Trade is unbelievably well implemented but might be hard to understand at first. I advise reading this page: http://gaming.stackexchange.com/questions/127786/what-is-the-point-of-trade-steering to learn more about it.This game provides you the chance to play with all countries in the world formed at that age. The problem for some might be the lack of a well defined goal. You don't really have victory conditions as in conquer A, B and C. Instead you get the choose. The game does provide you with missions which can help to guide you on your way but the goal is something you create yourself. Ones goal when playing as one of the native American tribes might be to just survive the Europeans landing in America. Since this game works with different techgroups and you're in a techgroup depending on your nation unless you're playing as a Western European nation you are going to fall behind in technology. You can change techgroups during the game but this comes at a cost.Now, I've already said a lot about this game and this is just the basic single player. There is a lot of support for mods out there and you can play multiplayer with up to 32 players. A big problem o the multiplayer might be that only the host has complete control of time and the rest can only pause the game. This means that the game might be going to fast or to slow depending on your situation. That said, the option is there and although I haven't tried doing it Lan, I believe that the best way to play this game might be LAN with some of your friends, while you backstab the hell out of each other.short version? If you need constant action this game is NOT for you. If you are someone who likes strategy games, are willing to spend a lot of time and deepen yourself in the game. Go and give it a try.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												This was the first true grand strategy game I played, and at first you feel lost. However you soon learn and the interface and it begins to make a lot of sense. Then the fun begins whether you turn a nation the size of the current vatican city into twice that of russia or just play the colonization game in the Americas, this game has a lot of variety as each nation has their own set of unique ideas. As well as all ethnic groups start at different levels of technology as European will be able to quickly discover guns while natives of the new world will struggle to learn this technology. War is always happening as each ai nation trys to win, so get good allies and defend or attack your enemy. Don't just expect the ai to just let you win (sometimes it feels like they will...) and when do win don't expect the world to be ok with your imperialistic desires as the ai will team up against you if you're to aggressive and reverse any "wrongs done".Some fun nations in my opinion are Brandenburg, England, Muscovy, and Korea.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Are you ready to abandon your family/pet/friends/girlfriend/life? Yes? Then hop in and try out Europa Universalis IV also known as the most addicting game in the history of games.When I started playing this game I thought to myself:"Okay, it's another 4X Grand strategy game from Paradox. EUIII was perfect? What can THIS offer?"And honestly... This is EUIII on the new version of Clauswitz. Literally. I could call this game EU 3.5, but I can't. Why? Because it's fun. Really fun. Even if it's just an improval over EUIII.The main thing for me about EUIV is that with the ammount of patches, DLCs and god-knows-what installed, you can really run your country the way you want. Enjoy being a diplomat rather than a warrior? No problem. The game gives you a right ammount of tools with which you can still expand your empire without even firing a shot.The great variety of gameplay styles and countries offers enormous replay value, uncomparable to other Paradox titles. Want a challenge? Start up as an indian nation and experience a completely different game! Instead of colonizing, sailing on the great seas and exploring, you are trying to defend your tiny nation against the foreign invaders. All of this said, EUIV is just a fun game. If you enjoyed previous Paradox titles such as: Europa Universalis III or Victoria II, EUIV will be a perfect title to fulfill your dreams of creating the Swiss Empire.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												This is the best strategy game I've ever played. Although very complex and not that easy to master, it's a very fun game to play. You can play as any country you want from 1444 - 1820. There are many amazing features in this game. You can have royal marriages with other countries, and then maybe the other country's king dies without an heir, and you can claim their throne and annex them. Another amazing thing about the game is that you can explore, discover, and colonize places such as the Americas. The game is not always historically accurate, since other countries can make different decisions instead of decisions that they actually made in real life. For example, the Portuguese colonized the Eastern coust of North America and Aragon annexed or conquered Castile instead of the other way around. But with different decisions it can make the game interesting, and YOU can make your own history.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												First got this game back in 2013, never read the manual (no surprise there) nor did I have any background knowledge of the game. After being frustrated by the steep learning curve, I gave up on the game and didn't revisit it until a good two years later. The second time around I did my homework prior and boy did the game really open up. Ask me two years ago if I would put 500 hours into this game it would be a hard no. Ask me today and I'll tell you how surprised I am I haven't reached the 1000 hour mark yet. The beauty of the game lies in its complexity and choice. Once you master the basic mechanics its really up to you how you want your run from 1444-1821 to pan out. You can go with the historical route and try to recreate history, or do something radically different and watch the world adapt and become something that could've been. You can focus on expanding militarily, diplomatically, or not at all. You can build empires from conquest, colonialization or trade. Every aspect of the game is well fleshed out and continues to be refined, with each patch more exciting than the last.Not gonna lie, Eu4 will take a long time to master (if indeed that is possible) but in all honesty the game is so diverse in its offerings that you will feel a sense of accomplishment every step of the way, regardless of how many hours you put into it. But I can promise you if you can put in the first 5 hours, the next 500 will come soon enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												The latest Grand Strategy game from the masters of Grand Strategy, Paradox Studios.  The game is daunting at first, but if you take the time to maybe go through the Tutorials you soon realize all the options before you.  You can play as any country that existed between 1444 and 1821.  You can essentially create a world empire as anybody if you play your cards right.  You can choose to revive the Byzantine Empire, form a real Holy Roman Empire, form a united Hindustan in India, or even conquer America as the Aztecs.  The options are limitless, and you can do so much to guide your empire throughout the near 400-year span of the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Europa Universalis IV is beautiful, deep, challenging, and fun.  I was an avid fan of the third installment of this series, and this sequel has not dampened my enthusiasm.  With EUIV, Paradox has shown a willingness to innovate and improve on something that was already considered excellent.  For any player interested in Early Modern History or looking for a complex but enjoyable strategy game, EUIV delivers.  Players may select any country worldwide starting at any point from the fifteenth century to the nineteenth.  Once selected, the player will guide that country in almost all aspects, shaping its fortunes through the Ages of Renaissance, Reformation, Enlightenment, Exploration, and Revolution.  The game is geared toward diplomacy and warfare with economics and religion being reasonably well-represented as well.  Internal politics are, mercifully, almost totally absent.  The AI for computer players - essential for a game with a diplomatic focus - is quite good, and tooltips even explain AI thinking for the player.Europa Universalis IV has few shortcomings, however, at times it shows signs of falling in the cracks between its two primary audiences: history buffs and strategy gamers.  Although EUIV is filled with excellent historical information reflecting extensive research, historians are likely to quibble with some of the cause-and-effect relationships established in some of the games systems.  They may also take issue with the preference for static modifiers over cause-and-effect based systems for elements like technological growth.  Strategy gamers are less likely to notice these problems and more likely to simply find the amount of historical detail in the game overwhelming.  With all that said,  EUIV is fun enough to overcome any minor complaints and become a favorite among its target audience.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												My favorite strategy game of all time. EU4 is a fantastic game for those who love history and more importantly; those who want a challenge. You play as just about any nation that existed on the globe from 1444 and from there on out you can pretty much change the course of history (which does change since just about every country acts differently each time).It is an extremely complex game that has changed dramatically over the course of its existance, with new patches and DLC altering how you play and add new functions and territories for you to conquer.You can colonize the americas, parts of africa, australia, and the many islands in oceania and the pacific.Your nation's religion give you certain bonuses, and you somehow feel compelled to spread it; be it christianity (catholic), islam, buddhism, hinduism, mormonism (okay that last one isn't in the game.. yet)You can conquer or diplomatically vassaile smaller nations, basically making them your puppets.The Holy Roman Empire is a thing; way too complicated to go into here but you'll get the idea as you play!rebellions, people who attempt to take your current leader's crown, peasants who are hungry, the 'french' revolution (can happen in any poorly administrated western nation) and historical country specific civil wars; like the war of the roses.the reformation! Change your christian belief if you wish from catholic to either protestant or reformed (like calvinist, I think) and reap the benefits/downside of now competing with your 'heretic' christian neighbours for religious dominance over the world.-Tons of other stuff! Like building famous important trade canals (Suez, Panama, Kiel) controling certain trade goods for 'perks' and bragging rights in a multiplayer game! (fur, silk, ivory, slaves, tea, coffee, chinaware, etc)Now for the bad news.STEEP LEARNING CURVE.Its difficult to understand how all the small details come together, and the game often seeks to punish you instead of teaching you why your sexy new territories are crumbling in rebellions, or why your 40 thousand army is losing terribly to an army half that size. It takes a long time to wrap your head around all of it, so you'd have to devote time and attention to be able to enjoy this game asmuch as those who regularily play it do.BY THIS POINT, SOME DLC IS A MUSTBuy this game when it is on a sale, because the number of DLC you'll want/need to get the full experience can rack up a hefty sum.TIME, YOU NEED TIMEThis is the sort of game, when you play multiplayer and to some extend, singleplayer you'll have to be prepared to sit there for a while. It isn't your 30 minute per game, game. Its your "we'll play for 5-6 hours and start again tomorrow" kinda game. Recommend quitting your job, breaking up with your girlfriend/boyfriend/right hand and putting the pizza delivery place on speed dial.====================================================================================And that is my review! Also, this game is nerd and asperger friendly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												 Probably the most accessible and intuitive grand strategy title out there, and definately my favourite game of all time. Playing as a historical empire from the years 1444 to about 1820, the choices really are completely yours. Engage in large scale diplomacy, conquest and trade while still maintaining a historical flair with flavoured events and descisions, but you can do whatever you like. Want to conquer Africa as Denmark, or play the Aztecs and bring the fight to the Europeans with a sunset invavion? No problem, though it may take you some time and effort. If you go into the game and feel overwhelmed by the detail, don't worry. The game makes sure that you learn as you play and there are plently of useful guides out there, not to mention the very good tutorial present in the game. Overall, if you enjoy strategy, history and conquering the world to your heart's content, this game is a must have. While it isn't the kind of thing that you can just dip into for ten minutes, the time commitment really is worth it for the amount of satisfaction and enjoyment that a great game like this can bring you. The DLCs are great, but the base game itself is worth the money many times over and the devs are still adding more content to the already richly detailed world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Firstly, if you like history (a lot) this game is for you.  If you like slower paced, thoughtful strategy games (like Civilization), this game is for you.  And if you like the challenge of learning a game that does NOT hold your hand this game is for you.Be warned--incredibly high learning curve for people who have not played the series before.  Crusader Kings 2 might be a better entry point for people who have never played a Paradox title before, because it has a lower (but still daunting) complexity.  That being said...This game is one of the most rewarding and engrossing strategy games ever made.  It ranks, in my mind, alongside games like Civilization Series, which I consider the gold standard of thoughtful slower paced strategy titles for the thinking man.  And MAN does this game wrack your brain.What this game does incredibly well is provide you with a wealth of options that boil down to 3 primary concerns: Expansion, Stability, and Technology.  All 3 are linked, but are ultimately competing with each other for your resources.The single most intersting feature of EU4 is in the Leadership points mechanic that is new to the series.  Instead of having technlogy points (like in past titles), EU4 introduces Monarch power, divided into Military, Diplomatic, and Administrative points.These points are CENTRAL to everything that you do.  Want to advance your technology in Military, DIplomatic or Adminstrative trees?  It costs Monarch Power.  Want to suppress the possibility of rebellion in a newly conquered region?  Military points.  Want to negotiate a punitive treaty against an enemy you beat soundly in war taking vast tracks of territory?  Diplomatic points.  Want to restabilize your country after the death of the previous monarch caused turmoil?  Administrative points.This creates a fascinating contrast between short term goals and longterm investment.  You don't want to spend too much of your power on expansion that taxes your resources on stabilizing your newly conquered territories only to watch yourself fall behind your rivals in technology and get dominated on the battlefield.  Yet expansion is kind of the point of the game, so finding that sweetspot, given other competing considerations and what transpires around you is an incredile exercise in short term and long term strategic balacing that is the hallmark of any great strategy title.Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												     Europa Universalis IV has all the width of an ocean (well, the width of earth actually,) but the depth of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ diamond mine and I've only done so much as stick my toe in to test the waters in my >60 hours played (I've got a good few hours played offline including 10 hours yesterday alone because people have said that some free patches make the game unplayable, more on this later).     This game is: not for everyone, not like Sid Meier's Civiliation, expensive, instantly gratifying, or easy. The game features complex (but not overly complicated) diplomatic and military systems like relations, colonization, trade, devlopement (or cores), and many things that can be accomplished through diplomacy or war like vassalization, establishment of protectorates, releasing nations, and claiming the crown of another nation. There are 3 different government types and further subdivision that offer unique bonuses like promoting of being more accepting of foreign cultures, electing leaders  with [x number of years] long terms so you can choose the leaders skillset more than one can in a monarchy. There is 4 currencies, the treasury and monarch points: Diplomatic, Administrative, and Military. You can play almost every nation that existed from 1444 to 1820 and choose whether to because a colonial trade power with enormous colonies is the Americas, Africa, and south east asia (playing tall) or establish a sprawling empire by annexing your neighbors through personal unions, conquest, or vassalization (blobbing). The game is a ton of fun with huge replayability with the only setbacks being the mass amount of DLC and a bit of Eurocentrism which can be expected by simply reading the game titles.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												I used to be a Total War veteran. Shogun, Rome, Empire. Then, during a sale, I decided to pick up Europa Universalis 4. It is a decision I have never regretted and Paradox have become my go-to studio for strategy games. I know people feel that the DLC is expensive and expansive; however, Paradox support their games far longer than most studios I can think of. In the end, the money-wise will collect this over a few of the larger Steam sales where you can often older DLC purchase it for up to 75% off. Time costs nothing, so you lose nothing exercising a little patience. EU4 will consume your time and no mistake. You may feel somewhat all at sea when you start as tutorials are not Paradox's strong suit, but given the complexity of the game how could you tailor one to cover all events? I recommend watching Let's Plays on YouTube; Arumba, Quill18, and Shenryyr2 were my educators and opened up the complete vista of what is possible in the game. From 1444, pick a nation and guide it to greatness. The mechanics are polished here; there are decisions to make, advisors to hire, technologies to chase, armies and navies to pursue your goals and extend your influence. Marry other nations and hope they die leaving no heir, so you become their ruler instead! Get involved in the religious wars; remain Catholic, or choose to become Protestant or Reformed in the Christian world. Muslim nations are bound to Shia, Sunni, or a minority of Ibadi, each with their own perks, and try and reunite Islam worldwide. Choose whether to become a local power, or take the relevant idea groups and become a colonial power. Explore the world, make Colonies and reap the rewards; be careful though, those enclaves far from home might get fed up with your lousy rule and desire liberty! There is so much here and plenty of choice. CIV and Total War are valid series, but they just don't have as much to offer as Crusader Kings II, Europa Universalis IV, or Victoria II.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Europa Universalis IV is the greatest empire builder ever. Be wary. You'll sink a LOT of time into this game. You can start as a lowly German state in the HRE and end up completely conquering Europe, if not the entire world. Difficulty varies from nation to nation. You can start out on the easy road, as a nation such as Castile, or go the hardcore way and start as one-province-minor Nagaur in India. This game is the pinnacle of alternate history. Paradox Interactive has done it again. One last warning. Don't expand too fast. Aggressive expansion kills.20/20 would get attacked by 16 coalition members again.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Some of these negative reviews are hilarious, and it's blatently obvious how butthurt some people are about the new Common Sense DLC. I have every major DLC except Common Sense, an I can say that my playing experience has not been deducted one bit. The game was not "chopped up" or "hidden behind a paywall" by Paradox, I have three different games running in EUIV, one in Europe, one in Asia, and one in Oceania. In all of my games I am a medium power, and I do not feel like not having Common Sense has put me at a disadvantage. The development system is nearly irrelevant, and is used mostly as a way to sink Monarch Points if you hit the cap.Europa Universalis IV is an amazing Grand Strategy game that cannot be ruined by one measly DLC, and I do recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												A grand game that will keep you busy for a long time.I wrote a few lines for this review but deleted those, and decided to say it short. It's addicting, it's fun, it's hard to get into, but if you do, you will enjoy it a lot. I was considering to demand a refund at first because I was too stupid, but after watching a couple of videos, I managed to start a game, and discovered the rest by myself. This is if not the, one of the greates grand strategy games on the market.And I have heard that the DLCs also add quite some features, and it is recommended to get them.I bought the Collection+ El Dorado and Art of War, because the DLCs were fairly cheap, and I would had also bought Common Sense, which is introducing a new diplomacy system. And since all those DLCs including the game (not all DLCs are included in the collection) I would either wait for Sales or buy the collection from a keystore, allthough the DLCs are not particulary cheap there.I strongly recommend the purchase of this game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												As grand strategy games go, Europa Universalis is the absolute leader. EU IV, the lastest installment in the series, improves much and doesn't break that much. Improved trade and better interface is what makes the game totally new, instead of an expansion pack. Most amazing thing in EU series is that you can pick any date between 1444-1810 (give or take a few years) and choose any nation, no matter how big or small, from all over the world. Try to take the world as Spain, or try to survive as Granada. Try to unify Europe as Habsburg Austria or try to overthrow Habsburgs as Cologne. Try to control Baltic Sea trade as Lübeck or play as Livonian Order and stop Russia from forming. Or- play as Kongo or Swahili or Mali to stop Portuguese colonists. Or unifiy India as the Hindu nation- or a Muslim one, if that ticks your fancy. Or repeat the success of the Ottomans- or as Mamluks, resist them. The list goes on and on and on. From America to Asia to Africa to Europe, the choises are straggering, the learing curve is steep and the feeling when your carefully thought out plan is ruined by your enemy declaring war on you is precious. If you like strategy games, this is THE game for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I'd like to start by saying, I loved Crusader Kings 2. I discovered the game a bit after it came out and loved it. I'd been a fan of Historical strategies for years and never expierenced the joy that CK2 brought. But when that game came to end in 1337, I was disheartened. I wanted more, more, more. When EU4 came out, I was hesitant. It was both similar and different from CK2. I started out as Portugal and found the trading, finance, and colonization mechanics unwieldy, different from CK2, and rather confusing, but there is a learning curve. Within 15 hours of playing the game, I considered myself good at the game. Over the next 70+ hours I took my small Iberian nation and conquered a third of Africa, 70% of the Americas, and all of Australia. When colonization was said and done I turned my military might on East Asia, Portapan, Portonesia, and Portuchuria soon became thriving colonies. Although they're simply tiles on a computer game board, I gain so much satisfaction from thrusting Europeans into places where they shouldn't be, namely Tibet. This game soon surpassed CK2 in both enjoyment value and hours played. When my friends asked me what I thought of the game, I didn't know how to answer. And even weeks later, it's still a hard question to answer. I really liked it, but not because of the mechanics or gameplay. I loved it because of the results, of seeing the green outline of the Portugese Empire, later to become a Republic, spread like a virus across the world. But this game is hard. Frustratingly Hard. Ironman mode is the only mode worth playing and it can be F***ing impossible. The Ottomans, French, Russians, Austrians, and Polish meddling with my plans and burning Lisbon to the ground. But following my defeat, I rebuilt my Empire/Republic prospered for the following decades, but I was still aggravated over my defeat, leading to several rage quits. Another cause for my frustration with this game was the mechanics. Early in the game, I couldn't figure out a good portion of the mechanics, and 100+ hours later, across several play-throughs, I still don't fully understand some of the mechanics. So to answer the question as to if I liked it or not. I didn't initially, and then liked the game, until I didn't, and then I liked. If your considering this game, ask yourself how much time you intend to put into the game. If you're like me and can put the hundred hours into the game to achieve mastery, then this is the game for you. If you don't think you'll get 30 hours out of this game, then don't get it. My rating from 0 to Great: Really good, but in about 10 hours, I may not think that anymore.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2013
												Europa Universalis IV. What to say? Well, first of Paradox had actually released a game that is perfectly playable on release! Infact, i haven't encountered much if any bugs yet. Game is very polished. Secondly, there are a lot of changes from EU3. Some systems had gotten the complete overhaul, other some tweaking, all in all, game still feels like a proper EU game, but with some major changes. In more detail, one of those changes is the technology and whole administrative side of things. Now you "collect" 3 types of points Military points (mp), Administrative points (ap) and Diplomatic points (dp). You gain them by your monarch skills (each point in skill = 1 point per month) and your advisors who range from 1 point per month cheap advisors, to expensive 3 point per month advisors. All advisors have same bonuses though, so for example, a lvl 1 Artist will gave same -10% stability cost as the lvl 3 Artist. Those points that you collect are than used on various things, researching technology, coring provinces, recruiting generals, signing peace deals, their importance is immense. One has to decide either to spend the points on something or to increase technology. Personally I prefered the old system of investing money, which made more sense, but apparently for Paradox the system wasnt intuitive enough for new players, so they changed it to that. The sliders are also gone. now you get ideas, which you spend your previously mentioned points on. So once you decide for some idea group, for example Offensive, you cannot remove it anymore, although you can take Defensive ideas aswell. Also with thoe idea groups, you have a national ideas group which is different for almost each nation which progress as you unlock more ideas. The other big change is the trading system. Centres of trade are gone, now you have trading lines, which can be influenced trough your actions provided that you have enough power on them so you gain money from them. You can either steer trade towards you, where you have power to collect money from them, or you collect it from somewhere where you want. It has some flaws, but overall an enjoyable system. Colonisation is quite similar to the old one, but tweaked so it's more enjoyable, and more meaningful because of the trading system. There are some problems i have though, overextension being the big one. Before you could conquer large chunks of land and you didnt overextend, now you conquer 3-4 territories to your huge empire, and all the sudden you are overextended, and a stream of bad events happens which you really want to avoid, so aggresive expansion to non core provinces really isn't an optimal way. Vassalizing lesser state and forcing Personal Unions is almost a better way of expansion as you get all cores when you integrate or annex a state. Another problem is border friction. You can try no matter how hard to be friendly with certain nation on your borders, but larger your border gets more impossible it gets. Border friction modifier gives a large hit to relations and a stream of events which your choices are either get a claim on a neighbour's land or -1 stab hit makes it even harder. So, if you are expansive soon all your neigbours will form a coalition against you, which means, if you attack or get attacked by any of them, you get into an automatic war with all coalition members, and you cant sign a separate peace, because coalition members must fight until end of a war.    All in all, the game is very enjoyable, im looking forward to future patches that can only improve the game.EDIT: 3 years after, it's still damn good :) Though there is a lot of DLC which might put off some people.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												The best diplomatic strategy game I've ever played, actually it's nothing like Age of Empires or Company of Heroes which you decide how you should command a battle to win the game; unlike, it's more like you should choose your strategy to advance your country for "centuries" like exploiting American coasts or conquer North African countries, vassalize them etc. You even play "Game of Thrones" to annihilate your rival. The good thing about the game is; it's more realistic than the 3rd game of the series, for an example you can make an alliance with your enemy's enemy which is really good. I highly recommend this game if you're into diplomatic strategy games, it's easy to play (not like Hearts of Iron) but if you wanna see the battlefield like in Total War Series you shouldn't waste your money. But just know that if you can like this game for once, Total War, Age of Empires or Company of Heroes will be like child's play for you and you'll literally think you wasted your money to buy these games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												First of all, I just want to point out the disgustingness of this game. For a game about creating alternate histories, Europa Universalis IV has some very firm opinions about what should happen to the peoples living in the parts of the world that aren’t Europe. None of them good. I don’t mean to say that it endorses genocide, merely that it doesn’t question it. The game accepts it as natural, inevitable, and unworthy of comment.There’s plenty of winking humor in how it treats the various atrocities that happened in Europe during this time, so I know they are aware of how things were horrible for many Europeans during that era. But there’s no clues to indicate that they really understand the horrors of colonization, as well.Everyone knows that religious wars and inquisitions and violently repressing your own people is wrong. But not everybody agrees that colonizing other nations is wrong, and that makes all the difference. It’s like how in Grand Theft Auto players can have a grand old time perpetrating mass murder on the streets of Liberty City, but many would have problems with a♥♥♥♥♥♥mini-game. We all agree murder is wrong, but♥♥♥♥♥♥is something people make excuses for.We all agree that dictatorships are wrong, but colonization is something we make excuses for.It’s an unsettled question. It’s a moral problem we have not yet agreed on an answer to. The distancing assumptions that allow us to vicariously enjoy the chaos of a 5-star rampage in downtown Los Santos are not available. Or, perhaps the assumptions are too available; perhaps the game relies on the assumption that moral question would never be asked.And so for those of us who are aware of the question, and who care about it, it’s not a very exciting premise for a game.It’s a fun game. A masterful game. A work of passion and talent. But I can’t enjoy it without reservations or recommend it without caveats. The moment you begin your colonization effort, the game takes a dark and troubling turn. It never really recovers from that. Now, if you don’t mind, I’ll be over here, attempting to unify the Holy Roman Empire into the modern state of Germany. And not doing any colonization.

content:

												Europa Universalis IV is the greatest empire builder ever. Be wary. You'll sink a LOT of time into this game. You can start as a lowly German state in the HRE and end up completely conquering Europe, if not the entire world. Difficulty varies from nation to nation. You can start out on the easy road, as a nation such as Castile, or go the hardcore way and start as one-province-minor Nagaur in India. This game is the pinnacle of alternate history. Paradox Interactive has done it again. One last warning. Don't expand too fast. Aggressive expansion kills.20/20 would get attacked by 16 coalition members again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												The latest Grand Strategy game from the masters of Grand Strategy, Paradox Studios.  The game is daunting at first, but if you take the time to maybe go through the Tutorials you soon realize all the options before you.  You can play as any country that existed between 1444 and 1821.  You can essentially create a world empire as anybody if you play your cards right.  You can choose to revive the Byzantine Empire, form a real Holy Roman Empire, form a united Hindustan in India, or even conquer America as the Aztecs.  The options are limitless, and you can do so much to guide your empire throughout the near 400-year span of the game.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												If you like to change the course of history with an alternate history all your own, you should play EUIV! Throughout the course of 377 years, you can guide your country (or any other) to either ruin or world conquest (not as Ryukyu though, that's impossible...). Play normally, or try for some of the extremely difficult achievements in Ironman Mode. This game has tons of replayability as you and the A.I. shape history for good or ill. Plus you get a good laugh from some of the hilarious things that can happen (i.e. : Hamburgian Scandinavia, Aragonese Iberia, Norwegian Manhattan, etc.). If you like to administrate your Empire, Paradox has you covered with buildings, development upgrades (Common Sense only), religion, culture, and a complex system of trade. If you like to blob the world (or a continent) with your country's name, culture or religion, you can do that too. If you buy this, have fun! And good conquering everyone!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24
												I have played this game a lot, there are things I really enjoy and they have kept me coming back, but many things I hate, which have ultimately led me to downvote it.Pros:1: The Aesthetics: The game looks pretty(ish). Graphics are good, art design is good. Seems right for the type of game. 2: The National Idea system is probably the game's strongest point. It allows you to taylor your nation's strength to suit your unique geopolitical situation. You can take policies that provide a variety of benefits in accordance with what you need where you are at. Whether you need a strong economy to maintain a large standing army for deterence, a strong navy to protect your thalassocratic empire, or strong dipomatic abilities to main a network of allies to protect you in a world of ambitious enemies. This systems works well, even in the worst of situations, and it is very enjoyable to watch your Ideas culminate to and get all these stacking benefits to perfectly suit your situation.3: The Colonial System: For anyone familiar with the period, colonialism is the cornerstone, and the game does that aspect very well. The main thing with it, is that when you establish enough colonies in a certain region elsewhere (e.g. Brazil, Canada, etc) the colonies form into a colonial vassal nation. This nation then becomes responsible for its own military, but is directly subordinate to you, and must pay tariffs. This takes some of the micromanagement away from you while still giving you the feeling of a global empire.4: Interesting Alternate History Potential: Alternate scenarios can play out if that is something you find interesting.5: Solid Nation Building: You can develop a lot of aspects of your nation, and can get the feeling of going from a tiny nation to a developed, global power. If you are not just conquered by some huge empire....Cons:1: Combat Systems: So the combat I would say is the worst part of the game. It's bad, and I mean really bad. To start, it is VERY numbers based. The person with the larger total military force wins. Pretty much a done deal. The problem is, the size of the military you can field, is entirely dependent on how much money you make a month becuase you need to balance monthly income, with monthly expenditure. Too many units, and you have to take out tons of loans which create problems. So you look for that sweet spot of breaking even. Larger nations, can obviously make more money, and thus, field a larger military. They also have a higher Land Force Limit (the number of regiments you can have which are free, you can go over, but it starts costing money) so they can not only afford to pay for more units over their limit, but they can just get more free units.This wouldn't be an issue if the game had an effective system for having higher quality units, but it really doesn't. Having higher quality units might net you enough to win in a relatively even battle, but if they outnumber you anymore than 50% you have virtually no chance of winning that battle. Or the war, and this ties into another aspect of the combat.The enemy can divide and conquer as much as they wish. For whatever reason, armies can travel between provinces VERY FAST. So much so, you can start a battle in southern Germany and the enemy could have time to run armies all the way from the northern coast of Germany to that battle and reinforce their units before the battle ends. So when the enemy outnumbers you, you can't even try to pick off isolated armies and destroy them while they are away from the main bul of their forces. Would be a good strat right? If you are fighting a larger nation, then maybe you could win by picking them off one at a time. Nope. The game factors that in by having battlefield reinforcement give huge moral bonuses to the army being reinforced, and provincial travel time very low.It goes like this.... Large nation declares war on small nation. Large nation divides up its forces into abunch of smaller regiments and besieges a dozen+ provinces of the smaller nation at one time. The smaller nation tries to pick off one of the split off armies. The large nation floods their armies into where that battle is happening to save the day. The large nation wins and annexes half the small nation's territory. 99% of the time, that is how it goes. There is no variance to this. The small nation can have a much better trained military force, doesn't matter. Better training and troop quality really doesn't mean much in anything but even battles, which are actually fairly rare. Usually wars are just one side♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the other.There is also little ability for smaller nations to get a larger military in times of need. Mercenaries exist, but you can only get so much of them at a time, and you need a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of money to get enough to matter. You can take out a ♥♥♥♥load of loans to buy abunch of mercenaries, but then you are so in debt that any victory is just pyrrhic at best. Maybe you fight the enemy off, but then it would take you decades to pay off those loans, meanwhile, truces only last 10 (way too short) years. So the large nation just waits a decade, you aren't even halfway to paying off your debt, they declare war again, this time you are too near your loan limit and you go bankrupt and they just anhillate you. It's a hopeless situation through and through. Whether you lose initially or over a couple decades, you just can't stop it. 2: Near Perpetual Cold War Between Large Nations: When one empire isn't just conquering the world, then you can have situations where two nations that oppose eachother, each have a network of alliances that prevent the other from attacking. These situations can leave you sitting around twiddling your thumbs for decades if not centuries because the defender is almost always favored. Both directly in battles, and in the larger scheme. Allies are far more likely to join defensive wars than offensive wars. So you can't attack your enemy because all his allies would join him and none of yours would join you, and visa-versa. It can get tiresome having the Cold War reenacted near everytime during the 1600s.3: Large Empires Invariably Snowball: Big nations can conquer huge swaths of territory. Alliances can keep them at bay, but many nations cannot effectively cultivate alliances and they get left out to dry. As such, the big neighboring empires always look at them and think "Oooo! Land!" and sweep them right up. I have not had a single playthrough where the Ottomans did not recreate the Mongol Empire having territory ranging from eastern Asia to Germany. I've seen them conquer Scandinavia more times than can even be funny. Scandinavia. The Turkic conquers of Scandinavia... One time is fun and interesting, but everytime highlights the sheer absurdity of this game. Also, coalitions are a joke. They are good in theory for stopping aggressively expanding empires, but fail to work on any decent level. I've seen maybe one effective coalition in my many hours playing the game, and that was against me because I simply ♥♥♥♥ed up.4: Rebellions Mean Nothing: In Crusader Kings a large empire can collapse from internal rebellion at the right time. That almost never happens in this game. Once you deal with initial rebellious sentiment from a conquered province it is almost never an issue again.5: Diplomacy: It really just involves improving relations and making alliances with the people who hate your enemies. Not much too it.The game has potential. To any fan of grand strategy and history (myself being one, hence the reason I tolerated the game's issues so long) it on the outset appears pretty good. But its issues really just manifest as time goes on. If you are interested in a historically authentic grand strategy game, that can capture the feeling of building a large, ancient empire, I would recommend Crusader Kings 2. It is similar at its core, but its mechnics are much better executed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												A fantastic addition to the current line of games from Crusader Kings II and the past Europa Series. If you are a historical buff like me you will enjoy it - although obviously it veers away from history a lot. As typical for the Crusader Kings and Europa games it is a very detailed nation-management game. The biggest let down of the game itself is how difficult it is to organise multiplayer games, and how utterly crap the AI is. You will struggle even surviving when you begin, but once you get the hang of it, the AI is simply no match at all. It becames a cake-walk. Some games quikcly become very boring. Another huge problem with this is the way the developer handle game content and updates - and this flaw spans all of their titles. The list of DLCs is huge. The costs individually are small, but over-all they add up to a lot of money. The problem comes when a new patch is released - which usually only happens when a new DLC is released. They always introduce changes to game play and mechanics that revolve around the DLC. If you don't buy the DLC, expect to lose a lot - even against the AI. The good thing is that almost all of the DLCs add to the game nicely and the developer is always patching and maintaining the game. Just frustrating to always be spending money on the game.Eu4 lacks the one thing I really loved about Crusader Kings II - Dynastic management. Maintaining some continuity for that within Monarchies would have been fantastic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Very addicting and fun to boot, whether you want to try and rebuild past empires like Rome or the Mongols, build new empires with Ulm, or "do it better" than historical empires like Spain or Great Britain, all can be accomplished with this deep and rewarding game.Multiplayer is fun, and you can play competitively or co operatively (or both!) with quite a few people at once (my highest amount being 38 players in one game). In addition, anyone playing multiplayer gets to use all of the DLC of the host, so you can try out features without purchasing the DLC yourself.A common criticism is the excessive amounts of DLC. Though there is a lot, not all of it is necessary and the majority of it is cosmetic. The Paradox Forums is a good place to find out what the best DLCs to get are, but the game is very playable without any of them.Overall, probably the most fun game and the best dollar to time ratio game I've ever played

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10
												This game is totally amazing. One of my favorite, helped me learn about geography a lot and some facts about history too. Some points have to be taken into account before buying it though.This game has very good replayability as it is possible to play as pretty much any country that existed in 1444, right after the rise of the Ottoman Empire. A ton of achievements to be earned makes it very fun to play. On top of that, there are many different ways of playing every single country, be it earning unions on other countries, changing the religion to Catholic in Korea or just painting the map with your color by eliminating all heretics.On the other hand, the devs have a very harsh way of making money, adding life-changing and completely necessary features in DLCs, so hopefully you can get those on a discounted price. Multiplayer is very buggy, it crashes often and getting the game started can be a pain.The learning curve is also tremendously high, many important parts of the game are not explained very well, therefore it may be a pain to get started but once you do, you won't be able to resist buying those 20$ DLCs.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												The game is fantastic.  It's unbelievable how much time I have sunk into it.  Don't worry about all the whiners about the DLC policy.  It's amazing how some people can spend 1000 hours enoying something that cost them just $60-80 (that's only .08 cents per hour of being entertained folks...good luck finding better value out of any other game) and still find a way to complain.   If you don't want the DLC, then don't buy it.  The vanilla game is still quite fun and will give you hours and hours of enjoyment.  Don't like one of the patches with FREE content the developers push out?  Simply roll your Steam install back to an earlier patch.  Personally, I have stayed at patch 1.11 for the last year or so because that was the sweet spot for me...to each their own.  How many other developers would bother to even keep patching a game 3 years after release?My advice - play the game on vanilla for a little while.  Get a feel for the game before you decide which new features in the DLCs suit your interest and style of play.  EUIV is more  than worth the time/money investment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												Most of the complaints about this game are the shoddy DLC strategy, which are somewhat true. At launch the DLC are very overpriced, considering the few features they bring. However, the main reason they have so few features is that most of their content is completely free. The game is almost completely unaffected by not purchacing the expansions (with a few exceptions, like development), and if they add a feature you don't like it's incredibly easy to revert to a previous patch. The expansions go on sale all the time, so if someone's whining about the price, they only have themselves to blame. I have 5 of the 8 expansions and I still haven't spent the $40 this game costs when not on sale, including the 10 spent on the game itself.Now that I'm done with the rant, on to the game itself. EU4 can be very unwieldy at first, but the menus aren't really as daunting as they first seem. If you first play as an easy nation like the Ottomans or Castille and get a solid ally or two, you can just play at your own pace, and learn the various systems like war, overextension, relations, trade, colonisation (depending on your country), religion, etc. Google is your friend! Hitting shift+tab while ingame brings up a steam menu which includes their internet browserI can't tell you if you'll enjoy the game or not, but if you want a game to take over the world it can't be beat. Civilization, Age of Empires, even Crusader Kings never really piqued my interest, but I can get lost in EU4 for hours.10/10, would crush the BBB again

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												 Probably the most accessible and intuitive grand strategy title out there, and definately my favourite game of all time. Playing as a historical empire from the years 1444 to about 1820, the choices really are completely yours. Engage in large scale diplomacy, conquest and trade while still maintaining a historical flair with flavoured events and descisions, but you can do whatever you like. Want to conquer Africa as Denmark, or play the Aztecs and bring the fight to the Europeans with a sunset invavion? No problem, though it may take you some time and effort. If you go into the game and feel overwhelmed by the detail, don't worry. The game makes sure that you learn as you play and there are plently of useful guides out there, not to mention the very good tutorial present in the game. Overall, if you enjoy strategy, history and conquering the world to your heart's content, this game is a must have. While it isn't the kind of thing that you can just dip into for ten minutes, the time commitment really is worth it for the amount of satisfaction and enjoyment that a great game like this can bring you. The DLCs are great, but the base game itself is worth the money many times over and the devs are still adding more content to the already richly detailed world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												You may look at this game and think "why isn't this used in schools? Kids could use a game like this to learn history." Now, while that is a totally valid point - it is really, really good for learning history - there's an unfortunate reason that Europa Universalis will never be used in schools.You see, this game teaches you the way the world works. It isn't one of those games that pretends everything's bright and peachy, and that you should always be fair to everyone regardless of race, religion or social standing. That isn't how this game works. Instead, lies, extortion, racism, genocide and just generally being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ are what guarantees success in this game; and most of those are also generally true for real life, though perhaps more four hundred years ago than today.I'm gonna launch into an extended metaphor now. This is what I imagine would happen if Europa Universalis was used to teach you moral values in school. So you're in suburbia, leaning over the fence and eyeing up a patch of your neighbour's land, maybe with some nice flowers on it, that your innocent and friendly neighbour waters every day, and you're claiming that this land is yours and you can use deadly force to get it.So you invade. You hop over the border fence, calling in your allies - those big bruisers from the ghetto suburbs - and, after sadistically beating your neighbour to a pulp and smashing all his stuff you demand that he give you the land. But even that isn't enough. You've done too much to only demand the land. So, after a nonchalant browse through your options you decide to take all his money too, and to demand a monthly payment of half his salary. Classic extortion, but how are you going to fund your conquests without the cash?But there's a problem. This new land, remember it has flowers on it? Well, those flowers happen to be hydrangeas. You don't like hydrangeas. They don't mesh well with the lavender in the rest of your garden. You'll need to employ some, er, drastic measures. So you get the gardener in for a low cost of a dozen diplo points, and he rips out the hydrangeas, digging deep to find the roots and piling it all in the street. Then he burns the lot of it, and you spread the ashes on the rest of your garden to help your gloriously superior lavender grow taller and stronger.Several years later, you've done the same to your other neighbours. Your personal lands are now tripled in size, with lavender growing everywhere. You've made your immediate neighbours bow to your will; they're paying you extortion money weekly now, and you've forced them to abandon their original cultures and join the lavender master race. You are the undisputed ruler of your street. Slowly, you're integrating the neighbours to make your street into one large plot of land with you at its head. Your past neighbours live in the cellar, serving you food and massaging your feet. And now it's time to move on to the next street. They must learn of the glory of your house.That is how Europa Universalis works. Lying, stealing, beating up defenceless innocents, discrimination based on race and religion. But that's what makes this game great. It doesn't matter who you play as, the path to glory will be the same. Be it a great European power, or a minor noble in India, or a North American tribe. Oppress your neighbours, take their land and money, and become a player on the world stage.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												From the studio that brought you Liquor Factory Tycoon comes the next big hit in photorealistic grand strategy: Aggressive Expansion Simulator! Navigate your way through some of the toughest questions of the Age of Absolutism, such as "on which type of church should I base my entire economy?" "Why is Denmark never happy with anyone?" and "just where is Poland now?"Chart your nation's course through history with exciting features, such as the coalition map mode, the stability and expansion tab, and the "declare war" button. While the game has its annoyances and drawbacks, such as the Imperial bureaucracy and France, it remains a timeless classic with tons of replayability. Also, there's a button that lets you kill natives on uncolonized land, which there's no real downside to, so just go crazy with it.(PS, this is MY land now, Habsburg, get over it already.)

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												I love EUIV. I wouldn't recommend buying it + all the expansions at full price because the game has now had so many that it's a lot of money. However, it's a very deep, well-researched, and very fun grand strategy game. You could buy the base game and play on an earlier version, as the Devs use the Steam betas feature to make all versions of the game available - which is excellent as many people have issues with most of the patches. Personally I think most if not all have improved the game substantially.There's so much depth in choice although if you're not interested in expansion through war then you're missing about 60% of the gameplay.It also runs reasonably well on what was a high-end laptop five years ago (i.e. no longer so good).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												17 tries in to forming a British empire. All other tries fail spectuacularly. France declares war, bringing in about 120k men. My navy holds them off. Then African Tribes do, sending in another 120k. Then spain takes my American colonies. Then Ottomans take my Indian ones. Then Civil war, and 120k spawn inside England. Gg. Game over. All within a month. Delete save. Then retry. That's the crucial part. This game is hard. Very ♥♥♥♥ing hard, especially when earning achievements. It's also monumentally complex, even more so with DLC. It will push your♥♥♥♥♥♥in repeatedly. But I always keep going back for more, and probably will for a very long time. That's what I love about it. Despite me hating it more than any game ever, I want to do it. I want to play it well. So gonna have to recommend, with the proviso that it's very hard, almost impossible half the time, and a lot of you wont like it. BITE SIZE CHUNKS:DLC: Too much, and some breaks the game. Colonies are nerfed without the right DLC, and that kind of thing. DLC effects are in the game, as they keep updating it for free, but to use them as intended you have to buy the expensive DLC. Or wait for a sale, as there's a lot. So that's kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Graphics: Solid. Simple. UI is a cluster♥♥♥♥, but there's so much going on it kind of has to be.Tutorial: Basically non existent. You will have to lose 9 million times, or youtube it. And half them will be outdated. Gameplay: Frustrating, but satisfying when it goes right. Very in depth, and strategic. Civ warfare is utter crap after this. Price: Wait for a sale, for the love of god. Do not buy this full price. Whilst it's immensely complex, so kind of justifiable, the fact some of the DLC is vital means you'll be shelling out even more dolla, so wait. Overall would probably rate a 7/10. Solid game, has glaring flaws, Sometimes not with the game itself. Constant updates too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												My only previous experience with Paradox's grand strategy games was Victoria 2 and I loved that game. So seeing the reviews for this game I thought I'd pick it up.This game is a whole other beast than Victoria 2. This game has complex poitical and diplomacy systems that would make Civ 5 and Total War fans turn green with envy. And don't get me wrong, I love the Total War games and Civ 5.If I was completely honest I do prefer Victoria 2 because I love the era of history more. But in terms of the mechanics as with only a little bit of game play and hours of watching instructional videos so I would know what I was doing, EU4 is a more impressive game than Victoria 2.There are some things like imposed force limits (which you can ignore because Paradox strategy games are awesome that way) that I don't really like, but I understand that it's meant to balance the game, add challenge, and reflect the time period since giant armies of hundreds of thousands was more of a 19th and 20th century thing.I don't know how much religion played a role in previous EU games since I didn't play them, but coming off Victoria it was a steep learning curve having to learn to deal with political entities like the Papal State and the Holy Roman Empire. The more I play the more I want to master this game and like many strategy/management games (like Railroad Tycoon II) I love this game, but it doesn't love me back. And I really am enjoying seeing what mechanic the game will throw at me next as I really start to feel like I have to do more than keep my economy from going bankrupt and invade my neighbors.I recommend this game whole-heartedly and now look forward to what I hope will be the announcement of Victoria III, which I hope uses a lot of the ideas and mechanics employed here so I can die happy.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												This is honestly the best Grand Strategy game I have played so far.It has everything I love in a historic strategy game: events, micro-management, warfare, conquest, diplomacy and internal politics. You can do practically anything: build a military juggernaut empire, establish a trade empire with complete hegemony over the world's commerce, build a religious crusader state to spread your faith to all four corners of the globe... Or just sit tight in your starting borders and try to not get conquered by your neighbors (I'm looking at you, Ulm) With patience and skill, you could take a nation that owns a single city and then over the course of a game raise it to superpower status. I've racked up over 400 hours of time playing this game and I still have yet to feel the slightest hint of boredom whenever I play it. It is truly a masterpiece and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone with a love for strategy, war and brutal cunning!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												I used to be a Total War veteran. Shogun, Rome, Empire. Then, during a sale, I decided to pick up Europa Universalis 4. It is a decision I have never regretted and Paradox have become my go-to studio for strategy games. I know people feel that the DLC is expensive and expansive; however, Paradox support their games far longer than most studios I can think of. In the end, the money-wise will collect this over a few of the larger Steam sales where you can often older DLC purchase it for up to 75% off. Time costs nothing, so you lose nothing exercising a little patience. EU4 will consume your time and no mistake. You may feel somewhat all at sea when you start as tutorials are not Paradox's strong suit, but given the complexity of the game how could you tailor one to cover all events? I recommend watching Let's Plays on YouTube; Arumba, Quill18, and Shenryyr2 were my educators and opened up the complete vista of what is possible in the game. From 1444, pick a nation and guide it to greatness. The mechanics are polished here; there are decisions to make, advisors to hire, technologies to chase, armies and navies to pursue your goals and extend your influence. Marry other nations and hope they die leaving no heir, so you become their ruler instead! Get involved in the religious wars; remain Catholic, or choose to become Protestant or Reformed in the Christian world. Muslim nations are bound to Shia, Sunni, or a minority of Ibadi, each with their own perks, and try and reunite Islam worldwide. Choose whether to become a local power, or take the relevant idea groups and become a colonial power. Explore the world, make Colonies and reap the rewards; be careful though, those enclaves far from home might get fed up with your lousy rule and desire liberty! There is so much here and plenty of choice. CIV and Total War are valid series, but they just don't have as much to offer as Crusader Kings II, Europa Universalis IV, or Victoria II.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Once you get past the overwhelming amount of things to do and manage, this game's a great simulator regardless if you enjoy the historical context or not. If you do, though, then it's worth noting this is probably one of my favorite history-themed games I've ever played. It does a great job of letting you play out both historically accurate events as well as entertaining "what if" scenarios. On top of that it does a great job presenting the history as well as providing a ridiculous amount of choices in regards to the time period, what nation/province you select (you can just about play as anyone from the individual Native American tribes in North America to the provinces of Feudal Japan depending on the time period selected), and what direction you go in.With mechanics like papacy control, royal legitimacy, colonization, religious reform, crusading, trade and National ideas (most of which is handled on a much more customizable and fun level than just some slider), there's a lot you have to decide on and manage. No two playthroughs are ever the same even if you pick the same nation. One game as Castile you may end up crusading into North Africa, colonizing the northwestern coast while fighting over the throne of a vassal state with a rival bordering you all while attempting to unify as Spain; In another game you may very well end up allied with the rival, instead focusing on your long-time ally of Portugal or the rising threat of France. Eventually you'll most likely end up doing all of these things, but it's entirely up to the player how the game pans out and makes for a lot of replayability. Be warned, though, just like most games like this, it eats up an insane amount of time and "campaigns" are incredibly long. Thankfully the game does a great job of constantly introducing new things to keep you hooked.Europa has a lot to it behind the simplistic presentation of the overworld map. It can be difficult and it can also be frustrating with random events that aren't entirely in your favor or seemingly impossible-to-beat situations, but if you can get past the initial barrier of getting into the game and enjoy a decent challenge it becomes as addicting as any good city/nation simulator and is a great game to play both single-player as well as with friends.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												I'd give the base game a 60, and the full game, with all the DLC a score of 94. What you want to pay is up to you, every DLC changes so much of the gameplay, it's like playing another game. EU4 has a total cost of 100 Euros (just the DLC, no Unit packs etc) + the base game (40 Euros at Steam, Februar 2016). With all the DLC, and some commitment, this game is the best strategy game i've ever played. Being able to chose from more than 100 Nations, each part of the world offering a unique gameplay in itself. With around 1000 hours of gameplay, I'm still learning. It's a very detailed game, unlike the Civilization franchise, with a lot of historical research coming into the game. This game can drive you mad when it tries non-stop to assassinate your 6/4/5 heir, but it can also be very satisfying, because there's no specific goal in the game, you can create your own goals or hunt achievements, which might not be too easy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												This game is intense. I'm a well-seasoned Civilization V player, and I had heard things about this game, so I gave it a go for the free weekend. My god. Never before have I had trouble in Civ with my diplomacy, economy, relations, discoveries, ideas, inventions that EU4 brings. I try to find similarities between the two; there are few, so if you are a serious Civ player, brace for a challenge. The interface is complicated, and progress is made slowly (you can't conquer another country in a matter of months), almost infuriatingly so. I wanted to colonize the Americas but it took so long for me to obtain a colonist that most of North and South America had been taken (still got Australia though). Overall, I do recommend this game. It probably takes more than 3 hours to get into a game, but hey, only had the weekend. And as I said before, if you're a Civ player, prepare your♥♥♥♥♥♥for your neighbouring countries to invade if you try anything funny.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												For any who enjoy Grand Strategy games, this is definitely worth giving a thought about playing. I think the best way to explain its worth is simply stating a few simple features of the game; You can play as over 500 factions, from any particular day out of over 400 years of history, with nearly anywhere in the entire world conquerable/coloniable, except for places that were too difficult to explore at the time. It's pausable, real time playstyle, can quite honestly be heavily addicting as there arent turns or missions that act as checkpoints, just you trying to shape your faction of choice in whatever way you desire, whilst struggling against an entire world trying to do the same. On top of all this it is also fully multiplayer with nothing lost in the progress, so you can try and ally together in a tough world with your friends or try to eliminate them and become the greatest world power. And above all, the goals you set yourself are mostly what guide you, allowing for many plays through as you try different cultures with different goals in mind. All in all, a great game that i recommend to many.

												Learn to fear comets just as your subjects do in this amazing pseudo-historical empire builder! Guide any nation on the planet to the level of world dominance that every dictator in history only dreamed about. Trade, marry, colonize, and war your way from 1444 to 1820 (or earlier and later with all the wonderful mods out there) to a large empire. Hate those lousy Brits? Conquer their puny island and destroy their annoyingly large navy! Dislike the smell emanating from France? Form large coalitions with other nations and take down France's stupidly good army! Want to show those smug Christians what Allah is all about? Play as a Muslim nation and convert provinces just for the fun of it! The choice is yours!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Europa Universalis IV is, simply put, an amazing strategy game about ruling a nation and (possibly) conquering the world or at least part of it.  You may rule a country of your choice from 1444 to around 1820, and if that doesn't sound like very long, that's probably 25 or so hours for one full playthrough.  Yes, they take a long time, but you want it to take a long time!  Facing diplomacy, trade, wars, and rebellions, among many other things, always leaves you wanting more.  Who will be the next nation to conquer part of?  Can you hold off from the pesky Spanish and Portuguese set on conquering the entirety of the world for profit?  Will you colonize the New World?Although the amount of units and the economy start to seem out of control in the lategame, I would certainly recommend EU4 to any lovers of strategy games as well as friends.  The AI can be enjoyable, but that could never match up to human players.If $40 is too much for you, it usually drops to $20 or even $10 in some sales.  And for $10, I would definitely recommend you pick this up and play it for a bit.  It's worth every cent.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												It's alright. Nothing special. Looks difficult and complicated as ♥♥♥♥ starting out but most gameplay mechanics either don't matter or don't need to be babysat. Played as Castile my first run and spent 2 hours attempting to lower inflation. Mods and multiplayer make the game really fun, as you can sit back and laugh with your friends as your vassal sates clash repeatedly in a series of proxy wars. Most people that complain about the difficulty curve don't realize that after 50 hours you begin to find out that the difficulty curve never existed in the first place. Most new players need to realize that most things don't matter in the short term. On the other hand, Paradox tends to buff/nerf things in big ways during major patches, and it might be weeks before a fix. Learn to ♥♥♥♥ with this game's files early, and you will be a much more happy man. EU4-Modding is mandatory8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												This is a great game for anyone looking to play a more challenging grand strategy game. It is the most beginner friendly Paradox game to date, and is still good for more advanced players. Expansions are added regularly and most do a good job of making the game more unique or different than it was before. There is also a dedicated community of modders who post mods ranging from graphical changes, to universe altering mods. The EU4 gaming community is a nice place, were inside jokes are exchanged and stories of conquest (or failure) are told. The game starts at around the time of the renaissance and ends about at the industrial revolution/Napoleon's reign in France. There is no main goal, just do what you want in this time period. Take over Europe as a Native American nation, colonize the whole new world, conquer the entire world. Or many more things! If you are good enough, you can do just about any historical or ahistorical action that you want to. Great for lovers of strategy and history, you might actually come out of a gaming session having learned about some real event or person. This game can actually teach you things about history. 9.5/10-Great game!

												A grand conquest like no other. In my opinion, the best of the Paradox interactive series, as it is set in the perfect timeframe, allowing any nation you choose to leave its mark permanently on the world. The interface can be somewhat daunting at the start, and it is very much a numbers game, but it manages this role so perfectly it can lead to hours of entertainment.
