number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												One of the greatest ways to tell if a game on Steam is good is to look at the reviews, and in particular the amount of hours played by those posting reviews.  In this case, I have given the equivilent of EIGHT MONTHS full-time work to this game.  There are many great aspects to this game, and relatively few drawbacks.Pros: 1) This is an excellent empire-builder that provides historical-based challenges and opportunities, so each country you play is differnet.2) The AI does a pretty good job of following history.  Spain colonizes the Americas quickly.  France blobs Western Europe.  The Ottomons and Mughals set up huge swathes of the middle east and asia, and Russia just takes over half the map.  Most of the time.  But every game is different, and maybe, just maybe, you might take control of the puny little Golden Horde and bring Asia to it's knees.  It can be done.  I've nearly managed it.  Just one more attempt, then bed, I swear!3) You can play as anywhere in the world.  Want to be technologically advanced Westerners? Sure, make things easy for yourself.  Want a challenge?  Start as spear-chucking African tribesmen and attempt to conquer the whole of Africa, despite the odds being stacked against you.  4) This game MAKES you think, and punishes you for the tiniest error in judgment.  Just like real life.  Cons:Forget how hard it is; Ironman difficulty or bust, I say!  But there are a couple of balance issues I am less than 100% happy with:1) Although you can modernise, or 'Westernise' your barbarian nations, and doing so means they will research technologies just as fast as the Europeans, you won't get access to western units (not since a patch).  To an extent, I can understand keeping the units diverse, but seriously, if my Mongols are more advanced than their Mughal neighbours, why are they still using the default start troops, while Mughals have professional soldiery?2) Truces last way too long, and there is too much of a penalty for breaking them.  If I take over half of my neighbour in one war, why would MY people be upset if I invade again the following spring to finish the job?  Other neighbours I can see being annoyed, but surely my loyal subjects should be singing my praises and awarding me triumphal processions through the capital!All in all, while there are balancing issues (that I actually think Paradox have made worse with patches, not better), I would recommend this game to anyone who loves grand strategy games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												If I ever find one of those Scandinavian B astards who made this game, I am going to kiss him and steal his girlfriend.  Thats how much I love and yet remain conflicted about Europa.  Its awesome, and somethings shouldn't be this awesome.  Buyer beware, this game is not to be taken lightly.  If you manage to get into Europa IV, you will be engrossed.  1000 hours is almost embarrassing but at this moment thats how much time I have spent in Europa, and I have ony scratched it, haven't played a game outside of Europe, and have so much left to do.  The price tag isn't worth it if you are looking to pick up a game to play for an evening or two.  Paradox's model plays to the gamer who wants ultimate depth.  I don't buy a lot of games, I play games that have a lot.  And no one does that better than paradox.  Between Europa and crusader Kings all other strategy games I have played are second class.  I still Play Civ 5, I know some people like to do the simulated battles in games like total war.  But in my opinion the game mechanics of both of those games are middle school, and Europa IV is getting a second doctorate after having already flown to the moon.  If you love strategy but don't love Europa then you only kind of love strategy.

												I have spent countless hours on this game just because it is so in depth and just overall amazing. With the  El Dorado DLC you can make your own country and have fun with that or you can play as an already existing country and change how history unfolds. I have almost never seen 2 games end up similar. Personally if I am not playing as France or Great Britain I don't like seeing them become the power houses of Europe so I end up either fighting against them or pouring money into their rivals countries.It is hard to go wrong with this game, if your friends have all the DLC and you play with them you can use all the DLC in his game if you don't have any of it. Paradox is still releasing DLCs for this game and at reasonable prices so I would highly recommend this game!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Europa Universalis 4 sometimes known as Eu4 is a grand stratergy game that covers the mid 15th to early 19th centuries. Unlike most games you have played Eu4 has no set goal. You can control any historical nation from the times above and craft it to your will, controlling the economy, trade, politics and most importantly warfare. I have only had the pleausure of  playing two games in this series. Eu4 and Eu3 and I must say that Paradox interactive have done a great job of making this rather niche genre more accesible to the casual gamer. Eu4 is much more fast flowing and has a much beter help system than its predecescors and has much more depth in terms of trade and diplomacy. overall i would probably give Eu4 a 7/8 out of ten the only reason I wouldnt put it higher is due to occasional bugs that i and other players have noticed. But still a great game for lovers of the stratergy genre. (If any new players want a game co-op or competitive please post below or send me a friend request.)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												My friends and I started up the game as 3 nations right next to each other. I had no idea how to play the game. Slowly, as the virtual years passed, I built up my army. There was a low chance of a rebellion occuring so I ignored it. I spent quite a bit of time gaining a good reputation with West Francia. I was going to use my allies to help me in a war over disputed territory. Finally, I declared war, and things started to look bad. I didn't include my most powerful ally and my other allies were slow to enter combat. I was having serious issues fighting off my enemies. And then, British troops, and other scrubs from some allies of the fools in my disputed territory I was in the war against started to come in. Things appeared better, we had just won a battle. But then, a rebellion occured in my country, and the last of my soldiers were defeated. My friends had already gotten peaces treaties and about 1/3 of my country was occupied by my enemies. It was over. I couldn't even make peace with some of my enemies. Just then, my friends told me we were going to start over. I clicked quit, and eu4.exe crashed. It was a fun time though.Overall pretty fun and not too pricey when on sale. Can't wait till I actually learn the game.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Over two years ago a friend recommended an "in-depth grand strategy game like no other" (based on his experiences with EUIII) and I was very sceptical at first, but eventually bought EUIV. I had no idea what I got myself into... Today, shortly before the new patch "The Cossacks" and almost 600hours of gameplay, I have to say: it is a fantastic and true grand strategy game! The guys from Paradox have done a fabulous job and the player-community whether it be on the forums, wiki, reddit or youtube and twitch is as vast, friendly and supportive as in the best way possible.In my opinion every buck spent on EUIV is worthwile as you get superb value for money. The exhaustion you feel after playing an entire campaign, the satisfaction you gain out of completing a challenging achievement, the entertainment-factor you get from watching the AI building the craziest empires - all that and more, makes EUIV an unique game. Every (major) DLC was great so far in adding more depth to this masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Starting from the start, I won't spend too much time on the positives, as they're just everything that isn't negative: Really great game, though maybe not as open as it could be, for newbies. Of course, it still is far more approachable than most other Paradox titles. But I felt that the tutorial is lackluster. I learned more from the loading screens than I did from the tutorial and tooltips. It's like; the tutorial teaches you all the basics which are pretty obvious and/or already explained via tooltips - but if you want some of the more hidden factors or components explained, you might be lucky enough to hit a loading screen which explains it, or you learn it given time. (As an example I spent a long time before I learned what shock and fire modifiers did, besides from obviously being the higher, the better)Another annoying, but far more subjective part, is the timeline. I've personally installed a 58-9999 timemod, because I feel the main game is too short; and even though it likes to brag about its replayability, it quickly turns into "something you have already done".The nation-creator from El Dorado feels like it should've been in the basic game. Paradox releases far too much DLC, it's getting scary. While I do realise most of these are flavour packs, the basic game just feels too barebones to not buy most of it.With those things out of the way:When you really understand the game (and again, I mean REALLY like, find a collection of the loading screens and read them all, because the tutorial does the game no credit), and if you have enough flavour packs and expansions to keep it varied, this is by far one of the most time-consuming and entertaining games. This is a wealthy man's videogame, make no mistake. But it is by far worth all the money.

												At first, it seemed a bit tedious. The game has mechanincs that can be hard to learn. I tried the tutorial and couldn't glean the information I needed out of it. I decided to jump right in. I got it while it was on sale for ten bucks, and if you go to the Paradox Interactive website, they almost always have most of the stuff for it on sale. It's an all around fun game. It can put you in place of any country, whether it be an Indian Raj, a Scottish Brus or a Native American chief. Once you learn the mechanics, the game itself is wonderful. If you're into grand strategy, this is the game for you. It almost never gets bored, and I dare say I'd compare it to Crusader Kings II in playability. If you've got the money to spare, get this game!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Of all the Paradox grand strategy games that I've seen or played to date, this one has definitely been the easiest to pick up and play. Do not, however, let this fool you. The game is certainly no cake walk and has a definite learning curve before you can get into it and play, but once you get a decent handle on the mechanics, this game is hugely entertaining. The ability to watch Europe, and later Asia, Africa and the Americas; develop as you play and see how history gets changed around based on the ever-changing interactions between nations is a definite point of interest if you've ever taken an interest in history. There are some issues with the military features, such as trying to work with your allies in wars when they have their hearts set on certain unrelated objectives, but it is not a considerable enough issue as to ruin the game. A definite recommendation from me, and a must-play for strategy buffs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												This is honestly the best Grand Strategy game I have played so far.It has everything I love in a historic strategy game: events, micro-management, warfare, conquest, diplomacy and internal politics. You can do practically anything: build a military juggernaut empire, establish a trade empire with complete hegemony over the world's commerce, build a religious crusader state to spread your faith to all four corners of the globe... Or just sit tight in your starting borders and try to not get conquered by your neighbors (I'm looking at you, Ulm) With patience and skill, you could take a nation that owns a single city and then over the course of a game raise it to superpower status. I've racked up over 400 hours of time playing this game and I still have yet to feel the slightest hint of boredom whenever I play it. It is truly a masterpiece and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone with a love for strategy, war and brutal cunning!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												My only previous experience with Paradox's grand strategy games was Victoria 2 and I loved that game. So seeing the reviews for this game I thought I'd pick it up.This game is a whole other beast than Victoria 2. This game has complex poitical and diplomacy systems that would make Civ 5 and Total War fans turn green with envy. And don't get me wrong, I love the Total War games and Civ 5.If I was completely honest I do prefer Victoria 2 because I love the era of history more. But in terms of the mechanics as with only a little bit of game play and hours of watching instructional videos so I would know what I was doing, EU4 is a more impressive game than Victoria 2.There are some things like imposed force limits (which you can ignore because Paradox strategy games are awesome that way) that I don't really like, but I understand that it's meant to balance the game, add challenge, and reflect the time period since giant armies of hundreds of thousands was more of a 19th and 20th century thing.I don't know how much religion played a role in previous EU games since I didn't play them, but coming off Victoria it was a steep learning curve having to learn to deal with political entities like the Papal State and the Holy Roman Empire. The more I play the more I want to master this game and like many strategy/management games (like Railroad Tycoon II) I love this game, but it doesn't love me back. And I really am enjoying seeing what mechanic the game will throw at me next as I really start to feel like I have to do more than keep my economy from going bankrupt and invade my neighbors.I recommend this game whole-heartedly and now look forward to what I hope will be the announcement of Victoria III, which I hope uses a lot of the ideas and mechanics employed here so I can die happy.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Summery/'TL;DR;CS paywall is not a dealbreaker, the game is amazing, paradox dlc policy is leagues ahead of most other companiesI must regretfully agree with many reviewers that some of the changes in common sense, particularily the development feature being behind a paywall is an issue, but I would argue that it is not a deal breaker to play without it, I did so for about 50 hours before picking it up on a sale. However commenters seem to be overlooking the incredible improvement to the combat system which completely changes the way you play, and the value of terrain and money. I would encourage anyone who picks this game up recently to try the origional system without 'super' forts. And that incredible improvement was free, just like dozens of other features in both this and CK2, so I personally see no issue in a play style being locked behind a paywall, (I don't think anyone complaining about it can say they havent gotten their moneys worth out of the game), although all this being said I have barely used the development mechanic, I prefer the subject interactions. besides gold is better spent on bribes mercs and boats than buildings. Hail Caesar!

content:

												So I picked up this game, and tried out the first scenario. The damn Ottomans kept on wrecking me, despite using one of the "reconmmended" forces. It was frustrating, but I learned a bit.Then I picked up the mod that begins in 50something AD, and lasts until 9999AD. I began at the start, going for a more peaceful route in North American Native Indian Expansion Simulator. Only to have the damn Iroquois attack me, but I conquered them. And the other neighboring tribes. I was finally beginning to understand how the mechanics of the game work. How things like stability and autonomy affect your nation. Then I realized I'd have to wait hundreds upon hundreds of years in game to finally be able to expand, Soooo I put an end to that.This time around, I chose the Uesugi clan in feudal Japan. With all the knowledge I gained, I was able to unify all of Japan, and have almost conquered the small island tribe to the north. But ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥... that Mongolian horde is freaking huge..... maybe I'll go eastward and proceed with peaceful Japanese North American Expansion Simulator....

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												I have been playing strategy games, on the PC, for a long time (20+ years). Europa Universalis IV has to be one of the best strategy games I have ever played in my entire life.What issues it does have (mine has a tendency to randomly crash on me whenever I attempt to load), are vastly overwhelmed by the positives. So much thought has gone into this game and it truly shows.I bought this game during a massive sale, and though I'm glad that I saved some money (as is my wife), I would have gladly purchased this game at full-price.One major negative, the DLC does feel like Paradox is "nickel and diming" the customers. Paying $10 for a DLC pack is one thing, but then to have "content packs" and other nonsense which should have, clearly, been included in the DLCs is ridiculous. That sort of business model will lose you customers guys; which is sad, because this is certainly a quality piece of software.

												The game is fantastic.  It's unbelievable how much time I have sunk into it.  Don't worry about all the whiners about the DLC policy.  It's amazing how some people can spend 1000 hours enoying something that cost them just $60-80 (that's only .08 cents per hour of being entertained folks...good luck finding better value out of any other game) and still find a way to complain.   If you don't want the DLC, then don't buy it.  The vanilla game is still quite fun and will give you hours and hours of enjoyment.  Don't like one of the patches with FREE content the developers push out?  Simply roll your Steam install back to an earlier patch.  Personally, I have stayed at patch 1.11 for the last year or so because that was the sweet spot for me...to each their own.  How many other developers would bother to even keep patching a game 3 years after release?My advice - play the game on vanilla for a little while.  Get a feel for the game before you decide which new features in the DLCs suit your interest and style of play.  EUIV is more  than worth the time/money investment.

The DLC for it is pretty good, but if you don't keep paying for DLC, then you'll end up with half-broken games, where the features are all there, but you can't use them.It's the best historical simulator to date, but even then it doesn't *really* capture the experience of history. For example, when people were colonizing the New World, they were chasing after all the gold early on, but in the game, you don't know if a colony will have gold until you actually settle it, which means you might as well just spam colonies in regions that have gold and hope to get lucky.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Great game. Pick a nation, paint the map your colour and create your own version of history. Probably the easiest Grand Strategy Game to get into. You don't really need any DLC from the start, it's good enough without them. If there's a deep sale, or maybe a bundle, then their importance goes something like this:Common Sense- allows you to develop provinces so you have something to do when not conqueringArt of War- a lot of quality of life improvements for all warmongersCossacks- estates, new diplomacy systemRights of ManWealth of Nations- trade, trade, tradeRes Publica- if you enjoy playing as a republic (or the Dutch)El Dorado- for meso and south american natives gameplay and Nation DesignerConquest of Paradise- north american natives and Random New World Generation which is still mehMare Nostrum- I don't even know what it addsOther than that you might consider Purple Phoenix (it's part of the pre-order bonus package), Star and Crescent (part of DIgital EXTREME Edition) and American Dream. They add some cool events and missions/decisions for Byzantium, Muslim Nations and USA respectivly.Rest of the DLCs add skins, music, some monuments on the map and one portrait pack so your muslim advisors aren't white anymore :).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												One nation offers you several types of gameplay. There are so many nations that are fun to play that one would never grow bored of this game. Singelplayer is all well and good, but the true fun is the multiplayer. You start off historically correct, then you shape the world in your imagine. England conquering Europe instead of colonizing, Castille/Spain taking provinces in Scandinavia, Native Americans repelling the colonization, An early Germany, A Polish Emperor, The ressurection of the Roman Empire. All of this can happen in one game. You would not regret buying this. The learning curve is quite steep, if you have not played EU III or CK2. But once you get it all down, it is simply amazing.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												A great game, if not a little on the simplistic side. Features decent abstractions of most of the period's features, although the mechanics lend themselves to being rather war-centric, which is not necessarily historical. Relatively easy to learn, compared to Paradox's other titles, however newcomers may be overwhelmed by the interface if they've never played with a similar interface, such as one from the Total War series. Definitely a good entry point into the grand strategy genre, as well as Paradox Interactive's other titles.

												If you have enough time to waste, and enjoy Grand Strategy games, this one is a very good bet.It's Paradox' 4th Europa Universalis, so anyone who has played Crussader Kings or Europa Universalis knows, what they are in for.Anyone who hasn't played any of these games, think this: Empire: Total War, remove Turns, remove Real-Time fights, put more diplomacy and more depth in, done.It has a very lengthy tutorial, and you should REALLY play the tutorial, or else you will not know what is going on.Other than that, i can only recommend this to anyone who wants to sink around 100 hours on a single campaign (i believe 11 or so exist, not sure on the number though).At the very moment, i have played 29 hours, and have only gotten as far as to conquer (modern) germany as austria.

												If you like any Sid Meiers game that is strategy I HIGHLY recommend this game, because you can form so many countries, so many interesting achievements to do that have a historical backround, and very good workshop with a a lot of good mods that range from nearly completely changing the game (in a good way) to just making the graphics a little bit better. Update: For someone who has 750+ hours on this game I have a teeny bit of experience with the DLC. What I think of the newest DLC is that realistically it seems rushed with bugs making the AI dumber than a rock (which for me is good) to making the Korean AI be like France x100. Not good. Especially with the new DLC announced which has some good things that we know of (by 2/27/16) like new African nations, I can for sure tell you that if people didn't like Estates (which are good if you know how to use them which for me was easy to grasp) they are going to HATE the territories and states and coring confusion B.S.Basically what I am trying to say is that when I got this game in Black Friday of 2014 it was well worth it but know its getting kinda crappy with the seeming rushed DLC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I'd like to start by saying, I loved Crusader Kings 2. I discovered the game a bit after it came out and loved it. I'd been a fan of Historical strategies for years and never expierenced the joy that CK2 brought. But when that game came to end in 1337, I was disheartened. I wanted more, more, more. When EU4 came out, I was hesitant. It was both similar and different from CK2. I started out as Portugal and found the trading, finance, and colonization mechanics unwieldy, different from CK2, and rather confusing, but there is a learning curve. Within 15 hours of playing the game, I considered myself good at the game. Over the next 70+ hours I took my small Iberian nation and conquered a third of Africa, 70% of the Americas, and all of Australia. When colonization was said and done I turned my military might on East Asia, Portapan, Portonesia, and Portuchuria soon became thriving colonies. Although they're simply tiles on a computer game board, I gain so much satisfaction from thrusting Europeans into places where they shouldn't be, namely Tibet. This game soon surpassed CK2 in both enjoyment value and hours played. When my friends asked me what I thought of the game, I didn't know how to answer. And even weeks later, it's still a hard question to answer. I really liked it, but not because of the mechanics or gameplay. I loved it because of the results, of seeing the green outline of the Portugese Empire, later to become a Republic, spread like a virus across the world. But this game is hard. Frustratingly Hard. Ironman mode is the only mode worth playing and it can be F***ing impossible. The Ottomans, French, Russians, Austrians, and Polish meddling with my plans and burning Lisbon to the ground. But following my defeat, I rebuilt my Empire/Republic prospered for the following decades, but I was still aggravated over my defeat, leading to several rage quits. Another cause for my frustration with this game was the mechanics. Early in the game, I couldn't figure out a good portion of the mechanics, and 100+ hours later, across several play-throughs, I still don't fully understand some of the mechanics. So to answer the question as to if I liked it or not. I didn't initially, and then liked the game, until I didn't, and then I liked. If your considering this game, ask yourself how much time you intend to put into the game. If you're like me and can put the hundred hours into the game to achieve mastery, then this is the game for you. If you don't think you'll get 30 hours out of this game, then don't get it. My rating from 0 to Great: Really good, but in about 10 hours, I may not think that anymore.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												An incredibly deep strategy game, with strong roots in history. This game lets you play out your global domination fantasies, starting in Renaissance Europe, in a fully simulated geo-political sandbox. The AI acts very rationally, in terms of their diplomacy and tactical decisions. When I lose, I curse Austria for outmaneuvering me instead of the developers, and that's a very good sign.One warning though, the learning curve is incredibly steep. I'd recommend this most to people who feel that games like Civ V have very simple mechanics - otherwise you may have some trouble picking this up.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												The best strategy game i ever played. It is a excellent game,but there are some points which should be stressed.1) Due to the new DLCs and mechanics used in the game(adding much more depth on the story),some achievments,specially the ones related to the expansion and domination became extremely hard, the calssical "follow the script" strategy which makes everything very boring in my opinion. It seems that Paradox intended to make a Empire Building game based on the classical domination,but at some point they began to reshape the gameplay into something more inclined to diplomacy,internal affairs, politics and less military(a decision which i support),but at the same time it made extremely difficult to achieve some achievments and conquests.So,if you are a achievment hunter,think twice about this game.2) if you are someone very perfeccionist and with a deep knowledge of history, you will notice some serious historical mistakes out of the "western Europe" political system. They seem to care mostly(almost only) with the classic western europeans(i know,the name says it),but i see some players in paradox community that are having the same complaints that i have about these things. I believethat  they do not give enough attention to others political systems which were equally relevant to mankind.Byzantine Phillipines and the wedding alliance between the orthodox Persia and Byzantium destroyed Rome. What else should i say :)
